links.description: webctl - A CLI for browser automation
links.summary: webctl is a command-line tool for browser automation designed for both AI agents and humans, built on Playwright and Chromium. Unlike MCP-based alternatives, webctl gives users control over what information enters their context by allowing filtering and piping of output through Unix tools before processing, avoiding context bloat. The tool provides semantic element targeting using ARIA roles, session persistence, and straightforward commands for navigation, observation, interaction, and waiting, making it suitable for scripting, debugging, or integrating with AI agents like Claude.
links.page_title: GitHub - cosinusalpha/webctl: Browser automation via CLI â€” for humans and agents

links.title: https://www.chroma-explorer.com
links.summary: Chroma Explorer is a modern native desktop client for ChromaDB that enables users to browse collections, perform semantic searches, and manage vector embeddings through an intuitive macOS interface. Key features include support for multiple database connection profiles, collection management with custom embedding functions, semantic search capabilities, integration with 13+ embedding providers, and document operations like batch management. The application is available for download on macOS 11.0 or later and provides a native user experience with modern design aesthetics.
links.page_title: Chroma Explorer - Modern ChromaDB Desktop Client

links.summary: Gleam is a modern programming language that combines a strong type system with functional programming capabilities, running on the battle-tested Erlang virtual machine to enable reliable, scalable systems that can handle millions of concurrent operations. It comes with comprehensive built-in tools including a compiler, formatter, and package manager, and can interoperate with thousands of libraries from the BEAM ecosystem written in Gleam, Erlang, or Elixir, while also compiling to JavaScript for browser compatibility. The language prioritizes developer experience through clear error messages, no null values or exceptions, and a welcoming community committed to inclusivity and respect.
links.page_title: Gleam programming language

links.summary: This Hacker News page aggregates discussions about various programming languages that have been submitted and discussed by the community over several months. The list features diverse languages ranging from well-known ones like Tcl and Red to newer or more niche languages like Jank, Koka, and Cyber, with engagement levels indicated by point counts and comment numbers. The page serves as a curated collection showing community interest in programming language development and innovation.
links.page_title: The $LANG Programming Language | Hacker News

links.summary: A Hacker News user curated historical collections of programming language announcements on the site, tracking posts titled "The {name} Programming Language" and "Show HN" programming language posts going back to notable releases like Go (2009), Rust (2010), and Swift (2014). The post sparked humorous discussion from users who initially mistook "$LANG" for an actual new programming language name, leading to creative jokes about what such a language might feature and references to existing languages like S-Lang and Slang.
links.page_title: The $LANG Programming Language | Hacker News

links.description: â€˜I rarely get outsideâ€™: scientists ditch fieldwork in the age of AI
links.summary: Scientists increasingly rely on AI, digitized specimens, sensors, and remote data analysis rather than traditional fieldwork to study ecology, enabling unprecedented monitoring of biodiversity at scales previously impossible. While this technological revolution offers significant potential for understanding ecological crises and global patterns, some ecologists worry that the shift away from hands-on fieldwork risks losing intimate knowledge of nature, introducing bias and oversimplification, and reducing engagement with local communities essential for conservation. The debate reflects a fundamental tension between the efficiency and scale of data-driven science and the irreplaceable insights gained from direct experience with the natural world.
links.page_title: â€˜I rarely get outsideâ€™: scientists ditch fieldwork in the age of AI

links.summary: The Cray-1 Computer System, introduced in 1977 by Cray Research, Inc., is a large-scale general-purpose supercomputer featuring both vector and scalar processing capabilities with a 12.5 nanosecond clock period and the ability to execute over 80 million floating-point operations per second. Designed primarily for the scientific community, it excels at solving complex computational problems in fields such as weather forecasting, aircraft design, nuclear research, and seismic analysis that require extensive data analysis and physical simulations. The system's configuration includes a central processor unit with 72-bit word memory (up to 1 million words arranged in 16 banks), twelve functional units, twenty-four input/output channels, and innovative error-correction technology, making it capable of performing computations previously infeasible for researchers.
links.page_title: The Cray-1 Computer System, 1977

links.description: Login to an emulated Cray computer via SSH
links.summary: This website provides access to an emulated Cray computer that users can log into via SSH or an in-browser client using the credentials crayusr/seymour. The simulator supports both command-line and graphical applications through X-forwarding, file transfers via SCP, and includes links to project documentation, source code on GitHub, and archived OS images for replication.
links.page_title: Cray simulator

links.description: An LLM trained only on 19th century data
links.summary: **TimeCapsuleLLM** is a GitHub project that trains language models from scratch exclusively on historical data from specific time periods and locations to eliminate modern bias and authentically capture the language, vocabulary, and worldview of that era. The project has released multiple versions (v0-v2) with progressively improving results, currently trained on 90GB of 1800-1875 London texts, demonstrating capabilities like recalling historical events and generating era-appropriate writing styles. The methodology, called Selective Temporal Training (STT), differs from fine-tuning approaches because it trains from scratch rather than building on pre-trained models, ensuring the AI genuinely reflects historical perspectives rather than merely mimicking them.
links.page_title: GitHub - haykgrigo3/TimeCapsuleLLM: A LLM trained only on data from the 19th century

links.description: Cowork - Claude Code for the rest of your work
links.summary: Anthropic has introduced **Cowork**, a new feature that extends Claude's capabilities beyond coding to help anyone automate everyday tasks like file organization, data compilation, and document creation. Available as a research preview for Claude Max subscribers on macOS, Cowork gives Claude access to designated folders on your computer, allowing it to autonomously complete work while keeping users informed and in control. The tool emphasizes safety through permission controls and user oversight, though users should be aware of potential risks like prompt injections and accidental file deletion.
links.page_title: Introducing Cowork | Claude

links.description: *To Name the Bigger Lie* - A biographical book with a mystery feel based on New Yorker essay
links.summary: Sarah Viren's memoir "To Name the Bigger Lie" interweaves two main narratives: her experience with a high school philosophy teacher who promoted conspiracy theories, and her later encounter with false sexual harassment allegations made against her wife. The book explores the nature of truth and how easily fact and fiction can blur, using these personal experiences to examine broader questions about reality, deception, and storytelling. Through the framework of Plato's Cave allegory, Viren investigates how lies can distort our perception of reality and how systems can legitimize fiction, making this both a personal memoir and a philosophical exploration of truth in the modern world.
links.page_title: Book review: Sarah Viren's 'To Name the Bigger Lie'  : NPR

links.summary: This is a recap of a podcast episode featuring tech experts making predictions about AI and technology for the years 2024-2026. The key predictions focus on AI's impact on software development, with notable forecasts including AI companies going on acquisition sprees, changes in software engineering careers, and the normalization of AI tools in professional programming. The experts generally predict a significant transformation in how code is written but stop short of predicting total economic or societal collapse from AI advancement.
links.page_title: Oxide and Friends | Predictions 2026!!

links.description: A software library with no code
links.summary: This article discusses a unique experiment: a software library called "whenwords" that contains no actual code, but rather consists only of specifications and tests that can be used by AI coding assistants to generate implementations in various programming languages. The author uses this concept to explore when traditional coded libraries might still be necessary versus when specification-only libraries could suffice, identifying five key scenarios where traditional code libraries remain valuable: performance-critical applications, complex testing requirements, need for support and bug fixes, importance of updates, and community/interoperability needs. The piece serves as a thought experiment about how software development might evolve as AI coding capabilities advance.
links.page_title: A Software Library with No Code

links.description: Linus Torvalds digital guitar pedal repo
links.summary: This GitHub repository contains Linus Torvalds' experimental work on digital guitar pedal effects, focusing on simple digital audio processing implementations like IIR filters and delay loops. The project serves primarily as a learning exercise, emphasizing basic, low-latency digital audio processing rather than complex effects like FFT-based vocoders, and includes a Python-based visualizer tool created with AI assistance.
links.page_title: GitHub - torvalds/AudioNoise at 71b256a7fcb0aa1250625f79838ab71b2b77b9ff

links.description: FUSE is All You Need - Giving agents access to anything via filesystems
links.summary: The article explores using FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) to give AI agents intuitive access to complex data systems by exposing them through a filesystem interface. Rather than building separate tools for each operation, FUSE allows developers to bridge their existing databases and APIs into a sandboxed filesystem environment, enabling agents to interact with data naturally through standard Unix operations like `ls`, `cd`, and file reading/writing. The author demonstrates this approach with a practical email agent example, showing how FUSE can translate filesystem operations into backend database queries, effectively creating a unified interface for both human users and AI agents to access the same underlying data.
links.page_title: FUSE is All You Need - Giving agents access to anything via filesystems | Jakob Emmerling

links.description: Self-hosting is fun with Claude Code
links.summary:
Self-hosting has become practical and fun in 2026 thanks to three convergent technologies: affordable mini PCs (under $500), simple networking via Tailscale, and AI CLI agents like Claude Code that handle infrastructure complexity. The author set up a home server running services like Vaultwarden, Immich, and others to replace SaaS providers, using Claude Code to automate Docker configuration and maintenance tasks that previously required extensive manual setup.

This approach is now accessible to software-literate people who want control over their data without becoming sysadmins, making self-hosting genuinely enjoyable rather than burdensome for the first time.
links.page_title: 2026 is the year of self-hosting

links.description: WikiData- a free knowledge base that anyone can edit
links.summary:
# Wikidata Summary

Wikidata is a free, open-source knowledge base containing over 120 million editable data items that serves as central structured data storage for Wikipedia and other Wikimedia projects. The platform allows both humans and machines to read and edit information, making data available under free licenses in standard formats that can be used by other websites and services. Users can contribute by editing items, joining WikiProjects, learning through tutorials, or using SPARQL queries to access and utilize the data.
links.page_title: Wikidata

links.summary: Librario is a pre-alpha book metadata API that aggregates data from multiple sources (Google Books, ISBNDB, and Hardcover) into a single unified response, addressing the problem that no single data source contains complete book information. The creator built it in Go to support a personal library management tool, using intelligent merging strategies to resolve conflicting data across sourcesâ€”such as scoring titles to penalize subtitles and evaluating cover images by quality. The project is AGPL-licensed, runs on a small VPS, and is available for public testing, with plans to add Goodreads and Anna's Archive as data sources.
links.page_title: Show HN: Librario, a book metadata API that aggregates G Books, ISBNDB, and more | Hacker News

links.summary: This article discusses why traditional read-only sandboxes are becoming obsolete for AI agents, introducing Fly.io's new "Sprites" - durable, disposable cloud computers that persist between sessions. The key argument is that AI agents like Claude need actual computers with persistent storage rather than ephemeral sandboxes, allowing them to maintain state and work more efficiently without rebuilding environments for each task. The solution offers the convenience of quick creation (1-2 seconds), durability, checkpoint/restore capabilities, and automatic idle metering, making it more practical for AI agent workflows than traditional containerized approaches.
links.page_title: Code And Let Live Â· The Fly Blog

links.description: Ferrite - A fast, lightweight text editor for Markdown, JSON, YAML, and TOML files
links.summary: Ferrite is a fast, lightweight text editor specifically designed for Markdown, JSON, YAML, and TOML files, built using Rust and the egui framework. The editor features WYSIWYG Markdown editing, syntax highlighting, multiple view modes (raw, rendered, and split), and advanced features like tree viewing for structured files, find & replace functionality, and MermaidJS diagram support. Notably, the project is transparently disclosed as being 100% AI-generated code (written by Claude via Cursor), with human oversight for product direction and testing.
links.page_title: GitHub - OlaProeis/Ferrite: A fast, lightweight text editor for Markdown, JSON, YAML, and TOML files. Built with Rust and egui for a native, responsive experience.

links.description: The concise Typescript book - an open source guide
links.summary: This appears to be a GitHub repository for "The Concise TypeScript Book," which is a free and open-source guide focused on effective TypeScript development. The repository's popularity is evident from its 9.6k stars and 578 forks, suggesting it's a well-regarded resource in the TypeScript development community.
links.page_title: GitHub - gibbok/typescript-book: The Concise TypeScript Book: A Concise Guide to Effective Development in TypeScript. Free and Open Source.

links.description: Summarizing and finding connections between books using Claude Code
links.summary: This article discusses using Claude (an AI) to find meaningful connections between different books through a technique called "trails" - sequences of related excerpts across multiple texts. The author built a system that allows Claude to analyze 100 non-fiction books, creating topic hierarchies and finding interesting thematic links between passages. The key insight is that AI can be used to deepen reading comprehension rather than just summarize content, with the author discovering that treating Claude as a collaborative agent with proper tools was more effective than using traditional pipeline approaches.
links.page_title: Reading across books with Claude Code | Pieter Maes

links.summary: This paper presents active inference as a first-principles framework for autonomous agent decision-making and compares it directly with reinforcement learning. The key distinction is that active inference minimizes expected free energy using a belief-based Bayesian approach, whereas reinforcement learning explicitly maximizes reward signalsâ€”enabling active inference agents to exhibit natural behaviors like epistemic exploration and uncertainty quantification without explicit reward engineering. The authors demonstrate these differences empirically on OpenAI Gym environments, showing that active inference can solve tasks without reward signals through preference learning over observations.

links.description: **Active Inference**Â - the process theory (or agent architecture) derived from the FEP that explains how organisms act on their environment to make their predicted observations come true. This framework unifies perception, planning, and action under a single imperative: to minimize free energy, which is an upper bound on the log-evidence of the agent's model of the world.
links.summary: **Active Inference**Â - the process theory (or agent architecture) derived from the FEP that explains how organisms act on their environment to make their predicted observations come true. This framework unifies perception, planning, and action under a single imperative: to minimize free energy, which is an upper bound on the log-evidence of the agent's model of the world.

links.description: An Incremental Approach to Compiler Construction
links.summary: This paper presents an incremental approach to teaching compiler construction by building a working Scheme compiler that generates Intel x86 assembly code. Rather than presenting compiler theory in abstract terms or jumping between simplified toy examples and complex industrial compilers, the author breaks compiler development into small, manageable steps where each iteration produces a fully functional compiler for an expanding subset of Scheme. The key takeaway is that compiler construction can be made accessible to novices by using a concrete, practical methodology with immediate, executable results at each stage.
Lend Me Your Ears - A musical ear training game
links.page_title: Lend Me Your Ears

links.description: miditu - An interactive terminal app/UI for MIDI composing, mixing, and playbackâ€”written in Rust
links.summary: **miditui** is an interactive terminal-based MIDI composing, mixing, and playback application written in Rust that provides a DAW-like experience with unexpectedly advanced features for a terminal app. Key features include a piano roll view, full mouse support (click, drag, scroll), real-time keyboard-based music composition using a QWERTY layout, unlimited MIDI tracks with mixing controls, timeline seeking, and support for importing/exporting MIDI, JSON, and WAV files. The application was developed with assistance from an AI coding agent and is now open-source, available for download or installation via Rust's cargo package manager.
links.page_title: GitHub - minimaxir/miditui: An interactive terminal app/UI for MIDI composing, mixing, and playbackâ€”written in Rust

links.description: How will the miracle happen today
links.summary: Through personal anecdotes of hitchhiking and traveling across Asia and America, the author explores how everyday miracles of human kindness occur when we approach life with openness and vulnerability. He argues that receiving generosity is an art form requiring a specific mindset of humility and trust, and that both the giver and receiver benefit through an exchange of gratitude and shared experience. The author suggests that by starting each day asking "how will the miracle happen today?" we position ourselves to recognize and accept the consistent kindness of strangers that surrounds us.
links.page_title: The Technium: How Will the Miracle Happen Today?

links.summary: This article is an introductory guide to 1ML, a type system designed by Andreas Rossberg for integrating ML-style module systems into programming languages. The author aims to demystify 1ML's technical papers for compiler authors by explaining how 1ML functions as syntactic sugar for System FÏ‰ (the core type system of Haskell) and walking through its key concepts, including the type system architecture, record field handling, and semantic types. The series is designed as a companion to Rossberg's 2018 paper and assumes readers have familiarity with type system notation, ML modules, and FÏ‰, with the goal of enabling them to understand 1ML's inference rules and implementation details.
links.page_title: 1ML for non-specialists: introduction â€” Christine's World Wide Web Site

links.description: 1ML is a reboot of ML starting from first-class modules, and unifies core and module layer into one small and consistent language
links.summary: 1ML is a redesigned programming language that unifies ML's core and module layers into a single, consistent language by making modules first-class values. This eliminates the syntactic and semantic duplication between the two layers while improving expressiveness, allowing functions, functors, and type constructors to be treated uniformly. The language is grounded in System F-omega and includes a prototype interpreter, with research papers published between 2015-2018 describing the design and extensions like effect polymorphism.
links.page_title: 1ML - core and modules united

links.description: Photographing the hidden world of slime mold
links.summary: Photographer Barry Webb uses macro photography and advanced composite techniques to reveal the hidden world of slime mouldâ€”single-celled organisms that are neither fungi, plants, nor animals but closer to amoebas. His stunning close-up images, captured with a high-powered macro lens and focus bracketing software, have won awards and showcase the tiny structures found in forests and deserts across western London. Beyond their aesthetic beauty, slime moulds play an important ecological role and have practical applications in urban planning and scientific research.
links.page_title: Slime mould - a hidden wonderland brought to life in photos

links.description: The Bytecode Alliance - WASM tooling projects
links.summary: The Bytecode Alliance is a GitHub organization focused on developing WebAssembly (WASM) tooling and runtime projects. Their main projects include **Wasmtime** (a lightweight, secure WebAssembly runtime), **WAMR** (WebAssembly Micro Runtime), and **wasm-tools** (CLI and libraries for WebAssembly manipulation), along with language binding generators and component model tools. The organization maintains over 100 repositories primarily written in Rust and C, supporting the broader WebAssembly ecosystem with standards-compliant implementations and developer tools.
links.page_title: Bytecode Alliance Â· GitHub

links.summary: WebAssembly (Wasm) hasn't disappearedâ€”it's actively used in real-world applications like Figma, Godot, and Squooshâ€”but it hasn't become the universal web development standard some predicted. The article clarifies that Wasm is fundamentally a low-level compilation target (similar to bytecode) rather than a replacement for JavaScript, excelling in specific use cases like running untrusted code securely, embedding computationally intensive libraries, and enabling cross-language portability. Its real strength lies in its strong security guarantees and efficient isolation capabilities, which enable applications like Cloudflare's code sandboxing and Figma's plugin system, rather than replacing traditional web frameworks.
links.page_title: What Happened To WebAssembly

links.summary: Model Context Protocol (MCP) has gained popularity as a standardized platform for AI integrations, but the author argues this popularity will be short-lived due to fundamental architectural flaws. While MCP aims to solve the "NxM problem" of connecting multiple agents to multiple toolsets, the author contends that existing frameworks already address this and that MCP's benefits come with significant costs: isolated tool instructions create incoherent toolboxes that confuse agents, separate processes introduce resource management and runtime dependency issues, and the lack of security standards has led to numerous CVEs and supply-chain vulnerabilities. The piece argues that MCP sacrifices the control and infrastructure that modern applications need for proper tool orchestration, logging, and security.
links.page_title: MCP is a fad | Tom Bedor's Blog

links.summary: This is MIT's "Mathematics for Computer Science" textbook (2018), authored by Lehman, Leighton, and Meyer, covering fundamental mathematical concepts essential for computer scientists. The comprehensive text is organized into five main parts: Proofs (covering logical reasoning, induction, and recursion), Structures (number theory, graphs, and networks), Counting (combinatorics and generating functions), Probability (random variables and distributions), and Recurrences (solving recurrence relations). The authors emphasize that proofs are central to both genuine mathematical understanding and computer science applications like software verification.

links.description: A basic implementation of Claude Code
links.summary: This article demystifies AI coding assistants by showing how to build a functional coding agent in just 200 lines of Python. The core concept is simple: the LLM doesn't actually modify your codeâ€”it sends tool requests (read file, list files, edit file) in a structured format, and your program executes them locally, then feeds the results back to the LLM in a loop. The author demonstrates that while production tools like Claude Code have additional capabilities, three basic tools are sufficient to create a powerful coding assistant that feels magical but is fundamentally just a structured conversation between an LLM and a tool executor.
links.page_title: The Emperor Has No Clothes: How to Code Claude Code in 200 Lines of Code - Mihail Eric

links.summary: Shipmap.org is an interactive animated visualization created by Kiln and UCL that displays the global movement of merchant ships throughout 2012, tracking cargo types and carbon emissions in real-time. The map allows users to explore five categories of vessels (container, dry bulk, tanker, gas bulk, and vehicles), filter by ship type, and observe shipping routes overlaid on ocean bathymetry. The visualization reveals the environmental impact of global maritime trade by displaying CO2 emissions and freight volumes, making complex shipping data accessible and engaging for research, education, and public understanding.
links.page_title: Shipmap.org | Visualisation of Global Cargo Ships | By Kiln and UCL

links.summary: Gwern argues that pessimistic technology forecasters make a critical error by assuming rigid, sequential paths to innovation and fixating on single obstacles to declare technologies impossible. In reality, most technological goals are "disjunctive"â€”meaning multiple alternative approaches exist, and success requires only one path to work while failure requires all paths to fail. By overlooking these alternative solutions and workarounds, critics suffer from functional fixedness and downward bias in probability estimates, as demonstrated by historical examples like the Manhattan Project and Edison's lightbulb experiments, where persistence through multiple methods ultimately succeeded despite individual failures.
links.page_title: Technology Forecasting: The Garden of Forking Paths Â· Gwern.net

links.summary: Watertown, MA is commemorating the 100th anniversary of Arshile Gorky, a pioneering Abstract Expressionist artist who lived in the city from 1920-1925 after immigrating from Armenia to escape persecution. The celebration includes multiple events and initiatives such as exhibitions, guided tours, a mural commission, and a city square naming to honor Gorky's significant impact on American art history and his important connection to Watertown's Armenian community.
links.page_title: 100 Years of Arshile Gorky | Watertown, MA - Official Website

links.description: This comment proposes that inheritance is still important to represent covariance/invariance/contravariance
links.summary: This Hacker News comment discusses the debate between composition and inheritance in object-oriented programming. The author advocates for composition (defining objects by their behaviors/capabilities) over inheritance hierarchies, while acknowledging that inheritance still has value for APIs requiring strict subtyping rules and variance handling (covariance/invariance/contravariance).
links.page_title: Yes I agree with you. The pattern is "composition" vs "inheritance". Defining a ... | Hacker News

links.title: What Features Should Rust Include? Part I: Not Inheritance.
links.summary: This article discusses programming language design principles, arguing that Rust deliberately excludes inheritance not out of tradition but through rigorous feature evaluation. The author contends that good language design requires features to work cohesively together, respect core invariants, and clear a high bar of necessityâ€”prioritizing clarity and collective engineering over individual convenience. Using inheritance as an example, the piece illustrates how Rust, influenced by functional programming rather than OOP, evaluates potential features neutrally rather than assuming they should be included by default.
links.page_title: What Features Should Rust Include? Part I: Not Inheritance. :: The Coded Message

links.title: Rust Is Beyond Object-Oriented, Part 2: Polymorphism
links.summary: This article explores how Rust's approach to polymorphism differs fundamentally from traditional object-oriented programming. While OOP relies heavily on a constrained form of runtime polymorphism through vtables that requires heap allocation, indirection, and prevents compiler optimizations, Rust offers multiple polymorphism mechanisms suited to different situations. The author introduces Rust's alternativesâ€”starting with enums (tagged unions)â€”which can often accomplish what OOP achieves through inheritance and runtime polymorphism, but with better performance and ergonomics.
links.page_title: Rust Is Beyond Object-Oriented, Part 2: Polymorphism :: The Coded Message

links.title: Rust Is Beyond Object-Oriented, Part 3: Inheritance
links.summary: This article argues that inheritance, one of the three traditional pillars of Object-Oriented Programming, is fundamentally flawed and unnecessary in Rust. The author clarifies that he opposes inheritance with shared fields (not interface implementation), explaining that "is a" inheritance is merely syntactic sugar for "has a" compositionâ€”making parent class fields implicit rather than explicit. The piece advocates for Rust's approach of using traits for polymorphism and explicit struct composition instead of inheritance, which provides clearer, more maintainable code.
links.page_title: Rust Is Beyond Object-Oriented, Part 3: Inheritance :: The Coded Message

links.description: Doom coding - Coding from your phone
links.summary: "Doom Coding" is a DIY guide that enables developers to code on their smartphones from anywhere with an internet connection using Tailscale, Termius, and Claude Code. The setup requires a computer running 24/7, a smartphone, and a Claude Pro subscription, with a straightforward 5-minute installation process that creates a secure remote connection to your home computer's terminal. The guide includes troubleshooting tips, best practices like tracking progress with Claude and previewing websites via HTTP servers, and demonstrates the author's success coding remotely during travel.
links.page_title: GitHub - rberg27/doom-coding: A guide for how to use your smartphone to code anywhere at anytime.

links.summary: This interactive guide explains how web browsers work by breaking down the process into digestible steps: from converting URLs into HTTP requests, to DNS resolution and TCP connection establishment, through to HTML parsing, DOM tree building, and the rendering pipeline (layout, paint, and composite). The guide uses interactive examples to help developers build an intuitive understanding of browser mechanics without overwhelming technical detail, emphasizing how the DOM serves as the central contract between the HTML parser, CSS engine, and JavaScript runtime.
links.page_title: How Browsers Work

links.summary: Play - MoirÃ© explorer
links.page_title: Play

links.summary: This GitHub repository curates practical, production-ready AI agentic patternsâ€”repeatable workflows and architectures that help autonomous AI agents perform real work effectively. The collection bridges the gap between toy tutorials and hidden industry practices by organizing patterns across nine categories including context management, feedback loops, orchestration, reliability, security, tool use, and user collaboration. Contributors can submit patterns that meet three criteria: they're used by multiple teams, improve how agents sense/reason/act, and are backed by public references like blog posts or papers.
links.page_title: GitHub - nibzard/awesome-agentic-patterns: A curated catalogue of awesome agentic AI patterns

links.summary: NeXTSTEP 3.3 (1994) was NeXT's Unix-based operating system featuring a Mach microkernel and advanced GUI that was ported to support several 32-bit HP 9000 PA-RISC workstations, marking NeXT's effort to expand beyond proprietary hardware after initial success on Motorola 68000 and Intel x86 platforms. The PA-RISC port supported specific models including the 712, 715, 725, 735, and 755 workstations with good onboard hardware compatibility, though limited third-party software availability restricted the port to version 3.3 only. While NeXTSTEP itself had limited commercial success, its innovative technologies and design philosophy influenced later systems like macOS.
links.page_title: NeXTSTEP on HP 9000 PA-RISC Computers â€“ OpenPA.net

links.summary: The author has built a system to run Claude Code agents on their iOS phone using a remote Vultr VM accessed via Termius and mosh, eliminating the need for a laptop or desktop. The setup uses Tailscale for secure private network access, tmux for session persistence, and push notifications via webhooks to alert the user when Claude needs input, enabling asynchronous development from anywhere. This infrastructure allows parallel development on multiple features simultaneously while keeping costs low (~$7/day) and risks contained to a disposable development environment.
links.page_title: Claude Code On-The-Go - Granda | Ideas & Code

links.description: Databases in 2025 - The year in review
links.summary: In 2025, PostgreSQL continued its dominance in the database world, with major acquisitions and new initiatives from tech giants like Databricks, Snowflake, and Microsoft investing billions in PostgreSQL-based services and DBaaS offerings. The year saw significant developments including PostgreSQL v18's new asynchronous I/O storage subsystem and growing momentum around distributed PostgreSQL projects (Multigres, Neki, and PgDog) that aim to add horizontal scaling capabilities similar to existing MySQL sharding solutions. Key takeaways include the consolidation of the PostgreSQL ecosystem through M&A activity, the emergence of competing open-source sharding middleware projects, and the establishment of PostgreSQL offerings across all major cloud vendors, solidifying its position as the dominant database platform.
links.page_title: Databases in 2025: A Year in Review // Blog // Andy Pavlo - Carnegie Mellon University

links.description: Scaling Latent Reasoning via Looped Language Models
links.summary: This paper introduces Ouro, a family of Looped Language Models (LoopLM) that integrate reasoning directly into the pre-training phase through iterative computation in latent space rather than relying solely on explicit text generation like chain-of-thought methods. The 1.4B and 2.6B parameter models achieve performance comparable to 12B parameter state-of-the-art models, with experiments demonstrating their advantage comes from superior knowledge manipulation rather than increased knowledge capacity. The work proposes LoopLM as a novel scaling direction for reasoning capabilities in the era of large language models.
links.page_title: [2510.25741] Scaling Latent Reasoning via Looped Language Models

links.description: claude-reflect - Add reflection to Claude Code
links.summary: **claude-reflect** is a self-learning plugin for Claude Code that captures corrections and workflow patterns to create permanent memory and reusable skills. It automatically detects when you correct Claude (e.g., "use gpt-5.1 not gpt-5") and syncs these learnings to configuration files like CLAUDE.md, while also analyzing session history to discover repeating tasks that can become automated commands. The system uses a two-stage processâ€”automatic capture via hooks followed by manual human reviewâ€”and supports multi-language corrections, making Claude progressively smarter about your specific workflows and preferences.
links.page_title: GitHub - BayramAnnakov/claude-reflect: A self-learning system for Claude Code that captures corrections, positive feedback, and preferences â€” then syncs them to CLAUDE.md and AGENTS.md.

links.summary: I don't have access to the actual content of that Hugging Face Space page. To provide an accurate summary, I would need you to share the full text content from the page. Could you please paste the main body text or description from the "Anatomy of BoltzGen" Space so I can create a 2-3 sentence summary focusing on the key topics and takeaways?
links.page_title: Anatomy of BoltzGen - a Hugging Face Space by ludocomito

links.description: Andrei Karpathy - Zero to Hero neural networks
links.summary: This is Andrej Karpathy's comprehensive course on building neural networks from scratch in code, progressing from fundamental concepts like backpropagation to modern language models like GPT. The course uses language modeling as the primary learning vehicle, as it effectively teaches deep learning principles that transfer to other domains like computer vision. The curriculum includes hands-on implementations of increasingly complex architecturesâ€”from basic neural networks and MLPs to convolutional networks and transformersâ€”with a focus on understanding the underlying mechanics rather than just using libraries.
links.page_title: Neural Networks: Zero To Hero

links.summary: John Hurliman experimented with ableton-mcp, an MCP server that enables Claude AI to control Ableton Live through tool-calling, extending its capabilities with 70+ custom automation tools including vocal-to-MIDI conversion and audio analysis. He equipped the AI with "ears" by integrating a Max4Live audio recorder and music analysis endpoints, then successfully created a mashup of "Octo" by Deft & Lewis James with GloRilla's "Yeah Glo!" using a combination of automated and manual workflows. The experiment demonstrates how modern LLMs can effectively learn DAW workflows and serve as collaborative pair programmers for music production, significantly accelerating the learning and creation process.
links.page_title: Experiments with ableton-mcp (Dec 2025) - John Hurliman

links.title: MyTorch â€“ Minimalist autograd in 450 lines of Python
links.summary: **MyTorch** is a Python implementation of automatic differentiation (autograd) inspired by PyTorch, using NumPy for computations and featuring a graph-based reverse-mode autodiff architecture. The library supports computing arbitrarily high-order derivatives for both scalar and non-scalar tensors, with a PyTorch-compatible API that includes `backward()` and `grad()` functions. While designed as an educational and extensible project rather than a practical alternative to PyTorch, it demonstrates how automatic differentiation can be implemented accessibly in Python and could potentially be extended to support GPU computation or neural network modules.
links.page_title: GitHub - obround/mytorch: Automatic differentiation implemented in python, inspired by Pytorch (easily extensible)

links.description: Most popular blogs of Hacker News in 2025
links.summary: This article ranks the most popular individual bloggers on Hacker News in 2025, with Simon Willison claiming the top spot for the third consecutive year due to his prolific AI coverage that prioritizes user insights over vendor pitches. The top five also includes Jeff Geerling (tech/hardware YouTuber), Sean Goedecke (staff engineer sharing tech organizational insights), Brian Krebs (investigative cybersecurity journalist), and Neal Agarwal (interactive web art creator). The piece reveals that success on Hacker News depends on a combination of factors including prolific output, authentic expertise, clear opinions, and an element of luck with timing and community engagement.
links.page_title: The Most Popular Blogs of Hacker News in 2025 Â· Refactoring English

links.summary:
of "The rsync Algorithm"

This technical report presents the rsync algorithm, which efficiently synchronizes files between two computers connected by slow, high-latency links by identifying matching blocks rather than transmitting entire files. The algorithm works by having the destination computer send checksums of its file blocks to the source computer, which then searches for matching blocks in its file and sends only the non-matching portions, along with references to matching blocks. The key innovation is a "rolling checksum" that allows rapid comparison of file blocks at any offset, making the algorithm practical for updating similar files with minimal data transmission and only one round-trip communication.
links.page_title: TR-CS-96-05.dvi

links.summary:
I'm Boris and I created Claude Code. Lots of people have asked how I use Claude Code, so I wanted to show off my setup a bit.

My setup might be surprisingly vanilla! Claude Code works great out of the box, so I personally don't customize it much. There is no one correct way to use Claude Code: we intentionally build it in a way that you can use it, customize it, and hack it however you like. Each person on the Claude Code team uses it very differently.

So, here goes. - Claude Code setup by creator
links.page_title:

links.description: Quickemu - Quickly create and run optimised Windows, macOS and Linux virtual machines
links.summary: Quickemu is a user-friendly wrapper for QEMU that simplifies creating and running optimized virtual machines for Windows, macOS, and Linux without requiring extensive configuration. The tool automates the setup process by automatically downloading OS images and configuring virtual machines with optimal settings for your hardware. It supports nearly 1,000 operating system editions and offers advanced features like file sharing, USB pass-through, clipboard sharing, and SSH port forwarding for both Linux and macOS hosts.
links.page_title: GitHub - quickemu-project/quickemu: Quickly create and run optimised Windows, macOS and Linux virtual machines

links.description: Lem - an extensible editor written in Common Lisp
links.summary: Lem is an extensible editor/IDE written in Common Lisp that supports multiple programming languages through built-in LSP support. It features a keyboard-oriented interface familiar to Emacs and Vim users, a GUI version with webview or SDL2, and comprehensive Common Lisp development tools including a REPL and debugger. The editor offers numerous modern features like multiple cursors, Git integration, and support for over 20 programming languages and markup formats.
links.page_title: Lem

links.summary: This essay argues that the internet has deteriorated from its early promise as a tool for learning, creativity, and genuine community into a corporate-controlled attention economy dominated by algorithmic feeds and a handful of giant platforms. Drawing on Ivan Illich's concept of "radical monopoly," the author compares the internet's trajectory to the automobileâ€”initially liberating but eventually demanding that society restructure itself around its demands rather than serving human needs. The piece calls for reclaiming "the Web We Want" by returning to principles of individual creativity, meaningful connection, and decentralized platforms that prioritize human flourishing over extracting shareholder value.
links.page_title: A Website To End All Websites | Henry From Online

links.summary: The author transitioned from Homebrew to nix-darwin to solve the problem of "imperative rot" on macOS, where manual package installations lead to unpredictable environments and broken configurations. Nix offers a declarative, functional approach using immutable configuration files and a lockfile system that enables perfect reproducibility across machines and easy rollbacks to previous system states. While Nix provides powerful benefits like ephemeral shells and comprehensive system customization, it comes with a steep learning curve and requires understanding complex concepts; the author recommends a hybrid approach combining nix-darwin for critical development tools with Homebrew for GUI applications.
links.page_title: Going immutable on macOS | A journey into a wild pointer

links.summary: Easel is a Clojure-based IDE that celebrates its one-year anniversary, designed as a modular "IDE as a library" where independent tools can share data and work together. The creator chose the JVM and Clojure as the foundation to solve hard problems like garbage collection and REPL-driven development, while addressing the softer challenge of building a modern UI library from scratch. The project is approximately 80% complete with major features already demonstrated, and reflects a philosophy of restoring computers as creative, collaborative toolsâ€”similar to historical systems like NeXTSTEP and Emacsâ€”rather than isolated applications.
links.page_title: Easel Turns One!

links.summary: This article appears to be a year-in-review piece about Large Language Models (LLMs) in 2025, though the specific content isn't fully visible in the provided excerpt. The page references related articles about LLM applications in 2026, including topics like using LLMs for porting open source code and predictions for the LLM field going forward. The main focus seems to be documenting significant developments and trends in the LLM landscape throughout 2025.
links.page_title: 2025: The year in LLMs

links.summary: Opal [Experiment] - Google Opal - Build mini-apps
links.page_title: Opal [Experiment]

links.title: Understanding How we Learn: a Visual Guide
links.description: Â by Yana Weinstein, Megan Sumeracki. A third way to organize similar ideas. Also combines cognitive science and education.
links.summary: "Understanding How We Learn: A Visual Guide" by Yana Weinstein and Megan Sumeracki is a practical resource that bridges the gap between cognitive science research and classroom practice. The book challenges educators' reliance on intuition and provides evidence-based strategies for effective learning, covering topics such as attention, memory, and cognitive processes. Through real-life examples, illustrations, and actionable tips for teachers, students, and parents, it offers accessible guidance on how to apply scientific findings about learning directly to educational settings.
links.page_title: Understanding How We Learn: A Visual Guide â€” The Learning Scientists

links.title: How Learning Happens: Seminal Works in Educational Psychology and What They Mean in Practice
links.description: Â by Paul A. Kirschner, Carl Hendrick. This book wears the research even more explicitly on its sleeve, but every paper is distilled into actionable content.
links.summary: "How Learning Happens" by Paul A. Kirschner and Carl Hendrick is a book that synthesizes seminal works in educational psychology and translates research findings into practical, actionable strategies for educators. The book distills complex academic research into accessible content while maintaining rigorous evidence-based foundations, making it a valuable resource for applying learning science to real-world educational settings.
links.page_title: How Learning Happens | Seminal Works in Educational Psychology and Wha

links.title: The ABCs of How We Learn

links.description: AI is forcing us to write good code
links.summary: AI-powered coding agents are pushing developers to adopt rigorous coding practices that were previously considered optional. The article argues that agents require strict guardrails like 100% code coverage, comprehensive testing, clear documentation, and strong typing to function effectively, since they can't self-correct like humans. The author's team enforces best practices including 100% test coverage (which removes ambiguity and forces agents to verify every line of code), well-organized file structures, fast/ephemeral dev environments that spin up in seconds, and end-to-end type safety to constrain the agent's possible actions and improve performance.

links.description: Apple model for 2D image to 3D representation
links.summary: Apple's SHARP is a neural network model that converts a single 2D photograph into a 3D Gaussian representation in under one second on standard GPUs, enabling photorealistic view synthesis and real-time rendering of nearby viewpoints. The approach achieves state-of-the-art results with significant improvements over prior methods (25-34% reduction in LPIPS metric) while being three orders of magnitude faster, and demonstrates robust zero-shot generalization across different datasets. The project is open-source and includes command-line tools for predicting 3D Gaussian splats from images and rendering video trajectories.

links.description: Read slow, eat slow for more enjoyment and satisfaction
links.summary: The article argues that we consume most thingsâ€”reading, eating, informationâ€”at default speeds that are too fast, which paradoxically reduces our enjoyment and comprehension of them. By deliberately slowing down consumption to about one-third normal speed, we extract significantly more meaning, pleasure, and satisfaction from the same activities, as the author discovered while reading Lord of the Rings aloud. links.summary: Volvo has commissioned London-based design studio Dalton Maag to create Volvo Centum, a new sans-serif typeface launching in 2026 as part of the company's centennial celebrations. links.summary: html2png.dev is a free, no-signup-required API that converts HTML directly into images (PNG, JPEG, WebP, or PDF) with a focus on being "agent-native" for AI workflows. The service offers zero setup, allows up to 200 requests per hour per IP, and supports advanced features like transparent backgrounds, Retina scaling, dynamic Open Graph images, and CSS selector targeting. links.description: Carnap - a logic framework in Haskell
links.summary: Carnap.io is a free, open-source logic framework built in Haskell designed for teaching and studying formal logic. It is widely used in logic courses at colleges and universities worldwide, offering students access to course materials and instructors the ability to implement logic instruction. The platform welcomes both students and educators, with options for course access and opportunities for those interested in contributing to or adopting the project.
links.page_title: Welcome To Carnap!

links.summary: The Computer History Museum acquired and published the source code for Adobe Photoshop 1.0, marking a significant preservation effort of computing history. This acquisition allows researchers and developers to study the original code that launched one of the most influential image editing software programs ever created. The preservation highlights the importance of archiving foundational software to understand the evolution of digital technology.
links.page_title: Adobe Photoshop Source Code - CHM

links.summary: Meta has introduced SAM Audio, an AI model that revolutionizes audio editing by enabling users to isolate and separate specific sounds from complex audio mixtures using text, visual, and time span prompts. The model supports multiple intuitive prompting methodsâ€”allowing users to extract sounds by typing descriptions (e.g., "dog barking"), clicking on video sources, or marking time segmentsâ€”making professional-grade audio separation accessible to everyone. SAM Audio is now available in the Segment Anything Playground for users to try, with potential applications spanning music production, podcasting, film, accessibility, and scientific research.
links.page_title: Our New SAM Audio Model Transforms Audio Editing

links.summary: Felt has introduced Lightning, a new technology that enables real-time editing of tiled map dataâ€”solving the long-standing tradeoff between fast-loading tiles and editable data. This breakthrough allows users to have both high-performance maps and the ability to make live edits simultaneously, eliminating the previous limitation of having to choose between speed or editability.
links.page_title: Introducing Lightning: Real-time editing for tiled data

links.summary: PLUM is a comprehensive directory of programming languages and systems designed for music composition, synthesis, and notation. The page lists dozens of specialized languagesâ€”ranging from notation systems like ABC to synthesis environments like Csound and Common Musicâ€”each tailored for different aspects of music creation, from algorithmic composition to real-time audio processing. Key takeaways include the diversity of approaches available (stack-based languages, Lisp-based systems, C libraries) and how these languages integrate with various music hardware and software platforms like MIDI, synthesizers, and digital audio workstations.
links.page_title: PLUM - Programming Languages Used for Music

links.summary: OpenSCAD is a code-based CAD tool that the author found surprisingly effective for designing simple 3D-printable objects. By reimplementing a parameterized battery holder originally created in Fusion 360, the author discovered that OpenSCAD can produce equivalent results without requiring expensive software, making it ideal for straightforward geometric designs like spacers and organizers. The approach uses simple variables and loops to generate customizable models that can be directly sent to a 3D printer.
links.page_title: OpenSCAD Is Kinda Neat â€“ nuxx.net

links.summary: The "block pattern" is a Rust idiom that leverages blocks as expressions to improve code organization and clarity. By encapsulating related operations (like configuration parsing) within a block assigned to a single variable, developers can clarify intent upfront, reduce namespace pollution, limit variable scope, and restrict mutabilityâ€”all while keeping code inline rather than splitting it into separate functions.
links.page_title: Rust's Block Pattern â€“ notgull â€“ The world's number one source of notgull

links.description: Reconsidering database design and optimization for SSDs and modern data centers
links.summary: Marc Brooker explores how database design should evolve for modern SSDs and cloud infrastructure, rather than relying on designs from the spinning disk era of the 1990s-2000s. Using quantitative analysis based on the "Five Minute Rule" and modern hardware capabilities, he argues that optimal databases should: maintain RAM caches for ~30-second access windows, use 32kB as the optimal transfer size for SSDs, replicate writes across availability zones to ensure durability, and leverage modern datacenter networks and hardware clocks for low-latency consistency at scale. The key takeaway is that while some core database principles remain valid, the dramatic improvements in SSD performance, network bandwidth, and infrastructure demand reconsidering foundational design decisions like write-ahead logs and page sizes.
links.page_title: What Does a Database for SSDs Look Like? - Marc's Blog

links.description: Skills officially announced for Codex CLI
links.summary: Agent Skills are task-specific capabilities that extend Codex with packaged instructions, resources, and scripts to help it follow workflows reliably. Skills can be created, shared across teams, and invoked either explicitly through prompts or implicitly when Codex recognizes a matching task, with flexible storage locations ranging from repository-level to system-wide scopes. Users can create custom skills using the built-in $skill-creator tool or install pre-built skills from a curated GitHub collection using $skill-installer.
links.page_title: Agent Skills

links.description: Great ideas in theoretical computer science
links.summary: CS251 is a Carnegie Mellon University course on theoretical computer science that rigidly examines the nature of computation through formal mathematical frameworks. The course is divided into two main parts: first, it formalizes computation by introducing finite automata, Turing machines, and exploring the fundamental limits of what can be computed; second, it studies computational complexity, including time complexity, graph theory, and the famous P vs NP problem. Key takeaways include understanding that most problems are undecidable, learning essential proof techniques like diagonalization and reductions, and grasping why the P vs NP problem is crucial to mathematics, artificial intelligence, cryptography, and optimization.
links.page_title: CS251

The tool is available now for production use and will continue toward a Stable release next year, with plans to eventually power additional semantic capabilities across Astral's developer toolchain.

The text serves as a foundational resource for understanding the physics underlying semiconductor devices and technology, which has been transformative to modern society since the mid-20th century.

links.description: Mystery Science Theater 3000: The Definitive Oral History of a TV Masterpiece
links.summary: Mystery Science Theater 3000 was a cult comedy series that featured a man and robot companions riffing on bad movies with witty, rapid-fire commentary. Created by Joel Hodgson and debuting in 1988 on a small Minneapolis TV station, the show became renowned for its clever, quick humor and cultural references that appealed to intelligent viewersâ€”earning fans like Al Gore and Patton Oswalt. Though never a major ratings success, MST3K became a beloved cult classic that fundamentally changed how audiences could interact with entertainment through comedic commentary.
links.page_title: Mystery Science Theater 3000: The Definitive Oral History of a TV Masterpiece | WIRED

links.description: Twins reared apart do not exist - The shaky science of genetic determinism
links.summary: David Bessis argues that the famous "twins reared apart" studies used to support genetic determinism are fundamentally flawed and misrepresented. He challenges Paul Graham's viral claim that identical twins raised separately show nearly identical IQ differences, contending this pseudoscientific data oversimplifies the concept of heritability and misrepresents what it actually means for individual lives. Bessis emphasizes that even with significant heritability figures, environmental factors remain crucial, and heritability only becomes practically deterministic at extremely high levelsâ€”debunking the oversimplified hereditarian narrative presented by popular figures.
links.page_title: Twins reared apart do not exist - David Bessis

links.description: Easier dev behavior with uv dependencies
links.summary: Simon Willison demonstrates how to use PEP 735 dependency groups with the `uv` package manager to simplify Python project development. By adding a `dev` dependency group (e.g., pytest) to `pyproject.toml` and including a `[build-system]` section, developers can run `uv run pytest` without manually setting up virtual environments. This pattern makes projects easier to contribute to and can be further enhanced by organizing dependencies into multiple groups (test, docs, etc.) that are included in the dev group.
links.page_title: Dependency groups and uv run | Simon Willisonâ€™s TILs

links.summary: This article chronicles 50 years of progress in proof assistantsâ€”computational tools that verify mathematical proofsâ€”starting with Edinburgh LCF in 1975. The field evolved from a niche, mathematically limited system through key developments like HOL and Isabelle, culminating in the mid-1990s when proof assistants gained credibility through practical applications like hardware verification and John Harrison's groundbreaking formalization of real analysis and floating-point arithmetic. The author argues that despite early skepticism from the broader computer science community, proof assistants represent genuine scientific and technological progress driven by academic research and government funding.
links.page_title: 50 years of proof assistants

links.summary: Abelian sandpiles are mathematical models on grids where sand grains topple between cells when a cell contains four or more grains, creating intricate symmetric patterns. The key insight is that these sandpiles form an abelian groupâ€”meaning the order of toppling operations doesn't matterâ€”which connects them to abstract algebra and group theory. The blog explores how sandpiles can be added together and reveals that the "identity sandpile" (the special element that leaves other sandpiles unchanged when added) displays beautiful, nearly fractal-like patterns.
links.page_title: Beautiful Abelian Sandpiles

links.description: Open source medium format range-finder camera
links.summary: Photographer Albert Cornelissen designed the MRF2, an open-source medium-format rangefinder camera that combines modern electronics with analog photography. The camera features LiDAR-based autofocus, custom PCBs, and 3D-printed components, and can shoot multiple film formats while producing professional-quality images. Cornelissen has made the entire project freely accessible on GitHub, including 3D-printable files and instructions, allowing anyone to build their own medium-format camera affordably and contributing to the thriving DIY camera community.
links.page_title: This Photographer Built an Awesome Medium-Format Rangefinder, and So Can You | PetaPixel

links.summary: Stoolap is a modern embedded SQL database written in pure Rust that offers enterprise-grade features comparable to PostgreSQL and DuckDB with zero external dependencies. Key features include time-travel queries, MVCC transactions, cost-based query optimization, adaptive query execution, and semantic query caching, with benchmarks showing 81% win rate against SQLite and 92% against DuckDB. It supports standard SQL operations, 100+ built-in functions, and can be used as both an in-memory or persistent database library with a command-line interface.
links.page_title: GitHub - stoolap/stoolap: A Modern Embedded SQL Database written in Rust

# Turtletoy Summary

Turtletoy is a web-based platform for creating hand-coded generative art using JavaScript turtle graphics with simple commands like forward, turn, penup, and pendown. Users can design single-line artwork and export crisp, scalable SVG and GCODE files optimized for plotters, laser cutters, and CNC machines. The community-driven platform allows artists to share, browse, and remix open-source creations through shareable links.
links.page_title: Turtletoy

links.summary: **ace-window** is an Emacs package that provides fast and intuitive window switching by displaying labeled characters in each window's top-left cornerâ€”users simply press the corresponding character to switch to that window. Unlike the standard `other-window` command (which requires multiple key presses for many windows) or `windmove` (which needs four key bindings), ace-window combines speed and predictability into a single key binding, typically `M-o`. Beyond basic window switching, the package offers additional actions like swapping, deleting, and creating windows, along with extensive customization options for keys, behavior, and appearance.
links.page_title: GitHub - abo-abo/ace-window: Quickly switch windows in Emacs

links.summary: This article outlines "Slack Maximalism," a operational management approach that uses Slack as the central hub for all communication, task management, and workflow coordination. The methodology is particularly effective for live, reactive operations like event management or customer service, and includes 10 principles such as creating atomic channels with single purposes, using channels as work queues, automating incoming work, and replacing direct messages with channels to maintain team visibility. The author presents Inkhaven, a residential program, as a case study demonstrating how these principles streamline coordination across residents, staff, and external partners.
links.page_title: The 10 Principles of Slack Maximalism - by Lucie Philippon

links.description: Georgia Tech - Online Masters in Computer Science courseware
links.summary: Georgia Tech's OMSCS program offers free public access to course content from 40+ graduate-level computer science courses through Ed Lessons, including lectures and exercises. However, enrolled students should use Canvas for their coursework, as the open courseware excludes graded assignments, projects, and the most current updates. This initiative provides aspiring computer scientists with access to high-quality educational materials across diverse topics ranging from AI and machine learning to cybersecurity and game design.
links.page_title: OMSCS Open Courseware

links.description: United States Antarctic Program Field Manual
links.summary: The United States Antarctic Program Field Manual is a comprehensive guide prepared by the NSF Office of Polar Programs that consolidates decades of field experience to provide essential procedures and safety protocols for personnel working in Antarctica. The manual covers critical topics including emergency management, field planning checklists for different deployment types, field camp operations, communications, survival equipment, environmental guidelines, and waste management. It serves as a practical reference for researchers and support staff to ensure safe, efficient, and environmentally responsible Antarctic fieldwork operations.
links.page_title: United States Antarctic Program Field Manual

links.summary: Literate programming, as originally envisioned by Donald Knuth, is a method of writing code that emphasizes top-down exposition and design discussion without being rigidly tied to structured programming's rules. Rather than forcing each design component into a separate subroutine, Knuth wanted programmers to decompose code chunks and explain their relationships while maintaining flexibility in implementation approach. The practical process involves writing problem statements, outlining program structure using named code chunks as pseudocode, rearranging chunks for reader comprehension, and only then writing the actual codeâ€”with Bob Nystrom's *Crafting Interpreters* cited as a successful modern example of this approach.
links.page_title: What even is "literate programming"?

links.description: A machine that does mechanical Fourier analysis
links.summary: Albert Michelson's Harmonic Analyzer is a nineteenth-century mechanical machine that performs Fourier analysis and synthesisâ€”decomposing complex periodic functions into their constituent sinusoids or combining sinusoids to create intricate patterns. Michelson invented the machine to automate the tedious hand calculations required for analyzing light frequencies from flames, improving upon earlier designs by using springs and levers instead of error-prone rope-and-pulley systems. The 80-element analyzer represents an elegant mechanical solution to a fundamental mathematical problem with applications spanning from image processing to data compression.

Aurora is a Linux-based workstation operating system built on KDE Plasma that prioritizes privacy, stability, and developer experience. It features automatic background updates with rollback capabilities, a unified app store through Flathub, and comes pre-configured with developer tools like Docker, Podman, and VS Code for containerized workflows. The OS is community-driven, easily auditable due to its open-source bash script and containerfile foundation, and includes expanded hardware support for graphics cards, GPUs, and peripherals.
links.page_title: Aurora - The Linux-based ultimate workstation

links.summary: The author argues that "transparent leadership"â€”which emphasizes coaching, teaching problem-solving, explaining organizational values, and making oneself redundantâ€”is superior to servant leadership as commonly practiced. While true servant leadership theoretically aligns with transparent leadership principles, in practice many managers mistakenly interpret it as removing obstacles for their team members, creating dependency and becoming overworked bottlenecks. The key takeaway is that effective leaders should develop their teams' autonomy and capabilities, then redeploy themselves to technical work rather than bureaucratic tasks.
links.page_title: Transparent Leadership Beats Servant Leadership

links.summary: The author built a remotely-controlled RC car using a Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W to monitor their home while away, addressing concerns about forgotten tasks like leaving the iron plugged in or the cat escaping. The project combines affordable hardware (2WD car kit, USB camera, motor driver) with a software stack including a Python motor control server, video streaming via mjpg-streamer, and an Nginx reverse proxy to unify services under one URL. To enable global access without exposing their home network, they implemented a Cloudflare Tunnel, creating a complete remote monitoring solution that demonstrates the surprising power and flexibility of running a full Linux computer on an affordable, palm-sized device.
links.page_title: I was reintroduced to computers: Raspberry Pi â€“ Physical AI is no longer science fiction.

links.summary: This article demonstrates how the infinite geometric series 1/4 + 1/16 + 1/64 + ... sums to 1/3, a mathematical discovery attributed to Archimedes around 200 BC. The page presents two elegant visual proofs using geometric figuresâ€”one with nested squares and one with nested trianglesâ€”where equal areas of black, white, and gray regions make the sum intuitively obvious without requiring algebraic calculation.
links.page_title: All the Way Down - Futility Closet

links.description: Program of Thought alternative to Chain of Thought
links.summary: This paper introduces "Program of Thoughts" (PoT), a novel prompting method that improves upon Chain-of-Thought (CoT) by separating reasoning from computation in numerical reasoning tasks. Instead of having language models perform both steps, PoT uses models like Codex to generate programs that express the reasoning process, while delegating actual computations to an external computer. The approach demonstrates approximately 12% average performance improvement over CoT across multiple math and financial datasets, achieving state-of-the-art results when combined with self-consistency decoding.
links.page_title: [2211.12588] Program of Thoughts Prompting: Disentangling Computation from Reasoning for Numerical Reasoning Tasks

links.description: Serve static websites for pennies a month
links.summary: trifold is a CLI tool that enables affordable static website hosting through a CDN (currently bunny.net), costing just pennies per month by charging only for storage and bandwidth usage. It provides an easy alternative to free services like Netlify and GitHub Pages, offering features like custom domains with SSL, cache management, and billing limits while maintaining reliability through a paid service. The tool is designed for indie developers and students building sites with static-site generators like Hugo or Zola, with typical costs remaining negligible for low-traffic sites.
links.page_title: trifold - trifold

links.summary:
This article explains how to write an effective CLAUDE.md file to help AI coding agents understand your codebase. The key principle is that LLMs are stateless and only know what you explicitly tell them in each session, making CLAUDE.md the ideal place to onboard Claude with information about your project's **what** (tech stack and structure), **why** (purpose and goals), and **how** (development workflows).

The main takeaway is to keep CLAUDE.md concise and universally applicableâ€”ideally under 300 linesâ€”because LLMs ignore irrelevant context and have limited instruction-following capacity (about 150-200 instructions). The article recommends using "progressive disclosure" by linking to separate, task-specific documentation files rather than cramming everything into one file.
links.page_title: Writing a good CLAUDE.md | HumanLayer Blog

links.description: Scala library for musical tunings and scales
links.summary: Scala is a comprehensive software tool designed for experimenting with diverse musical tunings, including just intonation, equal temperaments, microtonal scales, and non-Western scales. It offers an integrated suite of features for creating, editing, analyzing, and storing scales, plus the ability to generate MIDI files and tune electronic instruments. The software includes a graphical interface with 850+ commands, extensive online help, support for exporting to various synthesizers and music software, and access to a large free library of scales for both analysis and music creation.
links.page_title: Scala Home Page

links.description: Language is primarily a tool for communication rather than thought
links.summary: This Nature perspective argues that language functions primarily as a tool for communication rather than for thought, contrary to long-held theories. The authors review neuroscience evidence showing a "double dissociation" between language and cognitionâ€”demonstrating that complex thought can occur without language and that language properties are optimized for efficient information transfer rather than reasoning. They conclude that while language has transformed human culture and co-evolved with our cognitive abilities, it is not a prerequisite for sophisticated thinking but rather a powerful mechanism for transmitting cultural knowledge.
links.page_title: Language is primarily a tool for communication rather than thought

links.summary: James A. Garfield, the 20th U.S. President, published an original proof of the Pythagorean theorem in 1876 while serving as a congressman from Ohio. His clever proof uses a trapezoid methodâ€”calculating the area in two different ways to demonstrate that aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²â€”and is considered a notable variant of algebraic proofs. Garfield remains the only U.S. President to have made an original mathematical contribution.
links.page_title: Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean theorem - Wikipedia

links.description: An incredible set of math tricks and techniques
links.summary: This MathOverflow discussion explores Gian-Carlo Rota's observation that even brilliant mathematicians rely on only a few core techniques repeatedly throughout their careers. Rather than listing universal tricks, commenters clarify that Rota's point emphasizes that each mathematician develops a personalized set of deeply mastered methodsâ€”not that all mathematicians share the same tricks. The thread showcases specific examples including changing the order of summation, simplifying or complicating problems strategically, and in combinatorics, adding extra parameters to discover patterns.
links.page_title: soft question - Every mathematician has only a few tricks - MathOverflow

It comes ready to use out of the box and provides SDKs for multiple languages including JavaScript and Dart, making it easy to integrate with various frontend frameworks. The platform supports standard database operations like querying, filtering, creating, and subscribing to real-time record changes.

links.summary: This article describes a five-project compiler course (CIS531) designed to teach compiler design by building a progressively more complex compiler from scratch using the Racket programming language. Each project compiles a language with increasing featuresâ€”from basic arithmetic and variables (Project 2) to functions, lambdas, and closures (Project 5)â€”ultimately targeting x86-64 assembly. The course prioritizes rapid progress toward an expressive language over traditional compiler topics like register allocation or garbage collection, culminating in the ability to write substantial programs like a Sudoku solver.
links.page_title: Build a Compiler in Five Projects

links.summary: **Âµcad** is an open-source programming language designed to generate both 2D sketches and 3D objects, currently in active early development with regular updates and new features being added weekly. The project offers documentation including tutorials and a language book, provides live coding examples (spirographs, gears, domes), and is easily installable via Cargo, with the source code hosted on Codeberg. The language aims to enable parametric design and 3D modeling through code, as demonstrated by various example projects shared on the site.
