links.description: Jeff Tweedy Shallow Water Fairfield Circuitry pedal
links.summary: The **Shallow Water** is a K-Field Modulator pedal by Fairfield Circuitry priced at $425 CAD that creates unique, non-cyclical modulation effects through randomly modulated time delays. The pedal produces unpredictable pitch shifts and vibrato/chorus/flanger-like sounds with a vintage tape character by simulating a theoretical "k-field" where past and future forces interact irregularly. It's designed for musicians seeking unconventional, non-repeating modulation textures rather than traditional effects.
links.page_title:
Shallow Water
 â€“ Fairfield Circuitry

links.description: Using an LLM to extend AWK
links.summary:
Martin Janiczek created **FAWK**, a functional extension of the AWK programming language, using Claude (via Cursor Agent) to build a full interpreter in a single day. The project demonstrates that modern LLMs can successfully implement complex language features like first-class arrays, lambda functions, lexical scoping, and pipeline operatorsâ€”capabilities that traditional AWK lacks but that functional programming enthusiasts would find valuable.

While impressed by the LLM's capabilities, Janiczek acknowledges trade-offs: he lacks deep familiarity with the generated codebase and must now focus on code review rather than writing, raising questions about maintainability and whether LLM-assisted development is sustainable for long-term projects.
links.page_title: FAWK: LLMs can write a language interpreter | Martin Janiczek

links.summary: "WebAssembly from the Ground Up" is a resource created by Mariano, a co-founder of data analysis tools Gloodata and Instadeq with extensive expertise in programming languages and compilers. The page appears to be an educational guide about WebAssembly, drawing on Mariano's background in language design, compiler development, and high-performance computing from his work at IBM Research and Intel.
links.page_title: WebAssembly from the Ground Up

links.summary: Ai2 has released Olmo 3, an open-source AI model family designed to advance transparency in AI development by sharing the entire "model flow"â€”not just the final weights, but all training data, code, checkpoints, and development stages. The Olmo 3 family includes compact 7B and 32B parameter models with specialized variants (Base, Think/reasoning, Instruct/chat, and RL Zero), with Olmo 3-Think 32B serving as the strongest fully open reasoning model at its scale. An update (Olmo 3.1) introduces even more capable 32B checkpoints with improved reasoning and instruction-following abilities, demonstrating that open development and high performance can advance together.
links.page_title: Olmo 3: Charting a path through the model flow to lead open-source AI   | Ai2

links.summary: This GitHub repository provides tools to run historical UNIX versions on modern hardware, including Version 1, 5, and 7 UNIX for PDP-11 systems (via simulator) and Version 7 UNIX ported to x86 architecture. To use it, users need to install required tools like SIMH, QEMU, and Python, then clone the repository and run the setup script to download and install the UNIX disk images before launching their chosen UNIX version through either a command-line or Python GUI interface.
links.page_title: GitHub - felipenlunkes/run-ancient-unix: Easily run old versions of UNIX for PDP-11 on modern hardware

links.description: The lost cause of Lisp machines
links.summary: The author argues that nostalgic romanticization of 1980s Lisp machines is outdated and based on myths. While Lisp machines were impressive for their time (1983-1993), they became obsolete nearly 40 years ago due to rapid advances in general-purpose computing hardware and software, making their special-purpose design unnecessary today. The author systematically debunks common arguments for Lisp machinesâ€”including claims about superior development environments, performance, microcodability, and compiler efficiencyâ€”demonstrating that modern stock hardware and software have surpassed them in every meaningful way. The author's central message: rather than mourning the lost era of Lisp machines, developers should focus on building innovative Lisp applications today using readily available technology.
links.page_title: The lost cause of the Lisp machines

links.description: RowboatX - CLI Tool for Background Agents
links.summary: RowboatX is a local-first, open-source CLI tool that enables users to create and manage background AI agents with shell access for automating everyday tasks like meeting research, podcast summarization, and Slack message triage. The tool supports integration with multiple AI models (OpenAI, Anthropic, Google, Ollama, etc.) and Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers to extend agent capabilities. Users can build, schedule, monitor, and run agents through simple commands, with an optional web UI (Rowboat Studio) available for those preferring a graphical interface.
links.page_title: GitHub - rowboatlabs/rowboat: Local-first, open-source tools for automating everyday work.

Google DeepMind has introduced WeatherNext 2, an advanced AI weather forecasting model that generates accurate predictions 8x faster than previous versions, capable of producing hundreds of possible weather scenarios in under a minute on a single TPU. The model surpasses its predecessor on 99.9% of variables and lead times, offering higher resolution forecasts (down to hourly intervals) and is now available through Earth Engine, BigQuery, and Google Cloud's Vertex AI, while powering weather features across Google Search, Gemini, Maps, and Pixel Weather. Key innovation includes a Functional Generative Network architecture that enables the model to predict both individual weather elements and complex interconnected weather systems while maintaining physical realism.

The model excels not just at transcribing historical handwritten documents at expert human levels, but also at contextual analysis and logical inference needed to decipher unclear or ambiguous text. If verified, this breakthrough could revolutionize fields requiring both visual precision and skilled reasoning, such as historical research and document analysis.

This page is a comprehensive guide to programming language design that outlines the iterative process of creating a language and the essential knowledge required. The author emphasizes that successful language designers need expertise in three areas: programming paradigms, programming language concepts, and existing languages, supplemented by study of classic papers and design principles. The guide then provides a practical checklist for getting started, including defining your target audience, determining the language's philosophy (pragmatic vs. esoteric), and selecting foundational features that enable clear, readable code.

links.description: Spec-driven development - the waterfall strikes back
links.summary: Spec-Driven Development (SDD) revives waterfall-style heavy documentation practices to guide AI coding assistants, but the article argues this approach is counterproductive. While SDD promises structure, it creates excessive overheadâ€”developers spend 80% of their time reading verbose Markdown files rather than thinkingâ€”and fails to prevent AI agents from going off-track anyway. Instead, the author advocates for "Natural Language Development," an agile approach that breaks complex requirements into simple iterative tasks, allowing coding agents to build software efficiently through continuous feedback loops rather than upfront planning bureaucracy.
links.page_title: Spec-Driven Development: The Waterfall Strikes Back

links.description: Structured outputs on the Claude Developer Platform
links.summary: Anthropic has launched structured outputs for the Claude Developer Platform, now available in public beta for Claude Sonnet 4.5 and Opus 4.1. This feature guarantees that API responses match specified JSON schemas or tool definitions, eliminating parsing errors and failed tool calls while improving reliability for production applications. The capability is particularly valuable for data extraction, multi-agent architectures, and complex workflows where consistent, error-free formatting is critical.
links.page_title: Structured outputs on the Claude Developer Platform | Claude

links.summary: In the 19th century, popular science books democratized acoustic experimentation by presenting sound studies as entertaining, accessible activities for middle-class families and children. Building on Ernst Chladni's revolutionary 1777 experiment (which made sound visible through vibrating sand patterns), these primers encouraged home-based scientific discovery by blending rigorous learning with beauty and pleasure rather than detachment. This period of heightened "acoustic awareness" reflected broader Victorian fascination with sound and listening, establishing a progressive educational model that positioned science as playful intellectual discovery available to everyone.
links.page_title:
Hooked on Sonics: Experimenting with Sound in 19th-Century Popular Science
 â€” The Public Domain Review

links.description: The Paris Review and the CIA
links.summary: The Paris Review's co-founder Peter Matthiessen was revealed in 1977 to have been a CIA operative during the magazine's early years in Paris, sparking decades of speculation about whether the CIA influenced the publication. In a new biography, author Lance Richardson clarifies that Matthiessen joined the CIA primarily for practical reasonsâ€”seeking a stipend and an excuse to live in Paris as a young writerâ€”rather than ideological motivations, and found no evidence the agency actually used him to influence the magazine's editorial direction. However, the specifics of Matthiessen's CIA work remain largely unclear, as he left the agency in 1953 but never disclosed details about his assignments.
links.page_title: What Really Happened with the CIA and The Paris Review?: A Conversation with Lance Richardson by Dan Piepenbring

links.description: gemming - Generate images with Gemini Flash 2.5 Image
links.summary: **gemimg** is a lightweight Python package that provides easy programmatic access to Google's Gemini 2.5 Flash Image model for generating and editing images without watermarks or generation limits. The tool requires minimal dependencies, handles image I/O efficiently, and enables advanced features like multi-image editing, precise prompt control using Markdown formatting, and cost-effective grid generation of multiple images in a single API call. Key advantages include superior prompt adherence compared to traditional models like Flux, support for complex editing tasks, and the ability to guide generation using input images similar to ControlNet implementations.
links.page_title: GitHub - minimaxir/gemimg: Lightweight wrapper for generating and editing images from Gemini 2.5 Flash Image/Nano Banana

links.summary: Project Euler is a free online platform offering challenging mathematical and computer programming problems designed to combine mathematical insights with practical coding skills. The platform serves a diverse audienceâ€”from gifted students to adults and professionalsâ€”with over 1.37 million registered members from 220 countries using 113 different programming languages. Problems range in difficulty and are designed as an inductive learning experience, where solving one problem introduces concepts that help tackle previously difficult challenges.
links.page_title: About - Project Euler

links.description: Netflix - Using generative AI in content production
links.summary: Netflix provides guidance for production partners on responsibly using generative AI tools in content creation, emphasizing transparency and adherence to key principles. The guidance establishes that low-risk GenAI usesâ€”such as temporary creative aids that don't replicate copyrighted material, replace talent, or compromise data securityâ€”may not require formal approval, but any use involving final deliverables, talent likenesses, personal data, or third-party intellectual property requires written approval. Netflix expects all partners to report their intended GenAI use and follow strict protocols around data protection, ethical representation, and respecting performer consent and union requirements.
links.page_title: Using Generative AI in Content Production â€“ Netflix | Partner Help Center

links.description: deepwiki - AI-based overviews and chat about any repo/project
links.summary: DeepWiki is an AI-powered documentation platform that enables users to search, index, and have interactive conversations about any GitHub repository or coding project. The platform leverages AI to transform complex codebases into searchable, understandable documentation, allowing developers to quickly grasp how projects work through natural language queries rather than reading raw code. It features a curated list of popular open-source repositories spanning machine learning frameworks, web development tools, educational resources, and system design materials, making it easy for developers to explore and understand the projects most relevant to their work.
links.page_title: DeepWiki | AI documentation you can talk to, for every repo

links.summary: The Local Deep Researcher system provides a unified, pluggable search API integration layer that supports multiple web search services (DuckDuckGo, Tavily, Perplexity, and SearXNG) through a common interface. All search providers return results in a standardized format that enables consistent downstream processing, with configurable parameters for result limits, content fetching, and token management. The system allows runtime selection of search APIs through configuration while maintaining consistent data flow and processing pipelines regardless of which provider is chosen.
links.page_title: Search API Integration | langchain-ai/local-deep-researcher | DeepWiki

links.description: New Yorker article on resiliency - February 11, 2016
links.summary: Psychologist Norman Garmezy pioneered the study of resilience by identifying children who thrived despite severe adversity, shifting focus from vulnerability to protective factors. Research by Garmezy and later psychologist Emmy Werner revealed that resilient individuals share key traitsâ€”including an internal locus of control, autonomy, and access to supportive mentorsâ€”though resilience is dynamic and can strengthen or diminish depending on the balance between protective factors and life stressors. The findings suggest that resilience is both partly innate and partly learnable, offering hope that people can develop coping skills to overcome adversity throughout their lives.
links.page_title: How People Learn to Become Resilient | The New Yorker

links.summary: Peter Norvig's essay presents an elegant solution to solving any Sudoku puzzle using just one to three pages of Python code based on two key techniques: **constraint propagation** and **search**. The approach models Sudoku as a constraint satisfaction problem by representing each square's possible values and systematically eliminating options through two strategies: removing a digit from peers when a square has only one possible value, and placing a value in the only available square within a unit. The solution is implemented in Python by defining the puzzle structure (squares, units, and peers) and parsing puzzles into a dictionary representation that tracks possible digit values for each square.
links.page_title: Solving Every Sudoku Puzzle

links.summary: Tiled Words is a daily word puzzle game where players solve tiled word challenges. The game allows players to reveal up to 3 words per puzzle if they get stuck, providing a helpful hint system to aid in solving the puzzles.
links.page_title: Tiled Words

links.description: Novel solution to binary addition using a neural network
links.summary: A researcher trained small neural networks (with as few as 422 parameters) to perform 8-bit binary addition and reverse-engineered how they solved the problem. Rather than learning traditional circuit-like logic gates as expected, the networks developed a novel and surprisingly elegant solution that efficiently handled binary addition with overflow wrapping. By systematically reducing network size and rounding weights to interpretable values, the author was able to visualize and understand the internal mechanisms the network discoveredâ€”demonstrating that even tiny neural networks can learn complex logical tasks through creative, non-obvious approaches.
links.page_title: Reverse Engineering a Neural Network's Clever Solution to Binary Addition - Casey Primozic's Homepage

links.description: how did I get here trace route
links.summary: This webpage demonstrates a custom traceroute tool called **ktr** that visualizes the network path your data takes to reach the website's server. The site explains how traceroute works using ICMP packets with decreasing TTL values, while also educating readers about Internet infrastructure including autonomous systems (ASes), ASNs, WHOIS lookups, and BGP routing protocols. The author cleverly streams real-time results using HTTP server-push and CSS tricks, while noting that the displayed "reverse traceroute" from server to user provides an approximate (rather than exact) representation of the actual packet path.
links.page_title: How Did I Get Here?

links.description: How to use Claude Code like the people who use it
links.summary: This article features a podcast episode with Claude Code's creators from Anthropic, Cat Wu and Boris Cherny, who share insider tips on maximizing the AI coding tool's potential. Key takeaways include using "plan mode" for complex tasks rather than attempting one-shot solutions, standardizing team settings via a shared configuration file, leveraging stop hooks to automate task completion, and employing multiple subagents to catch bugs and handle tedious code migrations. The episode demonstrates how Claude Code has transformed development workflows at both Anthropic and Every, enabling faster feature development and empowering non-technical users to work directly with code.
links.page_title: ðŸŽ§ How to Use Claude Code Like the People Who Built It

links.summary: Joshua Blais has deeply integrated Emacs into his entire computing workflow, using it as a unified platform for nearly all tasks including email, file management, note-taking, password management, and terminal operations through custom keybindings and a Go-based launcher script. His motivation is to achieve a frictionless creative environment where thoughts can be immediately acted upon, with the added benefit of 10x workflow acceleration through his custom tools. While he considered using EXWM as a full window manager, he opted instead to replicate its functionality within the Wayland/Hyprland environment to maintain system stability and stay aligned with Linux's future direction.
links.page_title: How I am deeply integrating emacs - The Universe of Joshua Blais

links.summary: PLY (Python Lex-Yacc) is a zero-dependency Python implementation of traditional parsing tools that uses LALR(1) parsing algorithm to build parsers for programming languages, creating abstract syntax trees and compilers. However, as of December 2025, the project has been abandoned after 25 years of development, with the author recommending users consider alternative parsing libraries or continue using PLY by copying it into their projects. The tool is distributed as two simple files (lex.py and yacc.py) with minimal features by design, prioritizing flexibility and simplicity for educational and practical parsing tasks.
links.page_title: GitHub - dabeaz/ply: Python Lex-Yacc

links.summary: SLY (Sly Lex-Yacc) is a pure Python implementation of traditional lex and yacc parser-building tools that uses the LALR(1) algorithm for parsing. It offers extensive error reporting, supports Python metaprogramming for defining lexers and parsers without code generation, and can handle complex grammars suitable for real programming languages. However, the project has been retired as of December 2025, with the author recommending users explore other modern Python parsing libraries or continue using SLY independently.
links.page_title: GitHub - dabeaz/sly: Sly Lex Yacc

links.summary: Kimi Linear introduces a hybrid linear attention architecture that, for the first time, outperforms full attention mechanisms across various scenarios including short-context, long-context, and reinforcement learning tasks. The architecture combines Kimi Delta Attention (KDA)â€”an expressive linear attention moduleâ€”with Multi-Head Latent Attention (MLA), achieving up to 75% reduction in KV cache usage and 6x faster decoding throughput while maintaining superior performance. The researchers have open-sourced the implementation and released pre-trained model checkpoints, positioning Kimi Linear as a practical drop-in replacement for traditional attention architectures.
links.page_title: [2510.26692] Kimi Linear: An Expressive, Efficient Attention Architecture

links.description: A nocode web application that just uses an LLM and three tools
links.summary: Nokode is an experimental no-code web application that replaces traditional application logic with an LLM and three tools (database, web response, and memory management), eliminating the need to write code entirely. While the proof-of-concept contact manager successfully demonstrates that LLMs can handle application logicâ€”including inventing database schemas, writing SQL, generating UIs, and implementing user feedbackâ€”it suffers from severe practical limitations: it's 300-6000x slower, 100-1000x more expensive, and prone to hallucinations and memory issues compared to traditional applications. The author concludes that while the core capability exists today, the barriers are primarily performance-related challenges that may be solvable as AI inference speeds improve and costs decrease.
links.page_title: GitHub - samrolken/nokode

links.summary: Cartographer Andy Woodruff designed a completely rebuilt flight-tracking map for FlightAware that uses custom vector tiles and OpenStreetMap data instead of third-party services. The new map features significantly more airport detail, including terminal and gate information, while maintaining a dark, low-contrast style optimized for both general flight orientation and understanding airport surface situations. The map prioritizes airport information over surrounding areas to reduce file sizes for deployment across various platforms, including United and Alaska Airlines in-flight displays.
links.page_title: FlightAware map design - Andy Woodruff, cartographer

links.summary: Shrivu Shankar shares practical insights on using Claude Code effectively, emphasizing that success depends less on flashy features than on thoughtful setup. Key takeaways include: maintaining a concise, guardrail-focused CLAUDE.md file as your codebase's "constitution" for the agent; managing your 200k token context window strategically through /clear and custom documentation rather than relying on auto-compaction; and keeping custom slash commands minimal to avoid forcing engineers to learn unnecessary magic commands. The post prioritizes a "shoot and forget" delegation approach, judging tools by final outputs rather than interface style.
links.page_title: How I Use Every Claude Code Feature - by Shrivu Shankar

The community recommends several resources including **Bedrock** (a minimal starter kit with curated modern packages like Vertico and Consult), **SystemCrafters** (a comprehensive learning resource), and aggregated resources like Emacs News and the Emacs subreddit, while emphasizing that unlike Neovim, Emacs lacks a single authoritative figure but has an active community sharing evolving best practices.

links.summary: **nanochat** is a minimal, full-stack implementation of a ChatGPT-like language model that can be trained and deployed for approximately $100 on a single 8-GPU node in about 4 hours. The project includes everything neededâ€”tokenization, pretraining, finetuning, evaluation, and a web UIâ€”in a clean, hackable codebase designed to be educational and accessible. While the resulting model (2.2 billion parameters) performs below modern LLMs and makes frequent mistakes, it emphasizes full customization and transparency, allowing users to build and own their own language model from start to finish.
links.page_title: GitHub - karpathy/nanochat: The best ChatGPT that $100 can buy.

links.description: Micrograd - A small Python back-propagation implementation
links.summary: Micrograd is a tiny, educational Python library that implements backpropagation and automatic differentiation in just ~100 lines of code, operating on scalar values to build neural networks with a PyTorch-like API. It enables training of neural networks for tasks like binary classification and includes visualization tools to understand how gradients flow through the computation graph. The project is designed primarily for educational purposes to help understand how machine learning frameworks work under the hood.

**uv** is a revolutionary Python tool built by Astral that simplifies installing Python, managing virtual environments, and handling dependencies faster and more reliably than existing tools. It streamlines common Python workflows through commands like `uv sync` (to set up projects), `uv add` (to add packages), and `uvx` (to run tools instantly without setup), while ensuring consistent Python environments across multiple machines and developers. The tool's speed, ease of use, and ability to solve dependency conflicts make it transformative for Python development, particularly in collaborative projects.
links.page_title: uv is the best thing to happen to the Python ecosystem in a decade - Blog - Dr. Emily L. Hunt

links.summary: SpiderMonkey's developers created a custom graph layout algorithm called iongraph to replace Graphviz for visualizing their JavaScript compiler's optimization process. Unlike general-purpose tools like Graphviz, iongraph was specifically designed for control flow graphs and produces more intuitive, stable visualizations that better reflect the source code structure while remaining interactive and fast (implemented in under 1,000 lines of JavaScript). The algorithm leverages domain-specific knowledge about compiler graphsâ€”such as reducible control flow and explicitly labeled loop backedgesâ€”to simplify the traditional Sugiyama layout algorithm and deliver superior results for their specific use case.
links.page_title: Who needs Graphviz when you can build it yourself? | SpiderMonkey JavaScript/WebAssembly Engine

Their assessment reveals that current AI systems have uneven cognitive profilesâ€”excelling in knowledge-intensive tasks but lacking in foundational areas like long-term memoryâ€”with GPT-4 scoring 27% and GPT-5 scoring 57% on their AGI scale, demonstrating both rapid progress and the substantial gap remaining before true AGI.

links.description: Security duality: Mossad vs. not Mossad
links.summary: This humorous essay by James Mickens critiques the security research community's approach to cybersecurity priorities and threat modeling. Mickens argues that security researchers focus on obscure, impractical threats (like using Pringles cans to hack pacemakers) while neglecting real-world user needs like password management. He proposes a simplified threat model: either your adversary is "Mossad" (unstoppable), in which case elaborate security measures are pointless, or it's "not-Mossad" (manageable with basic precautions)â€”suggesting the security community should align their research with practical, everyday concerns rather than elaborate, unlikely scenarios.

The electron microscope evolved from a barely functional tool in the 1930s into a powerful instrument capable of revealing atomic-level detail, fundamentally transforming our understanding of biological structures. Invented by Ernst Ruska and Max Knoll in 1931, the technology overcame the resolution limits of light microscopes by using electromagnetic coils to focus electron beams instead of light, enabling scientists to visualize viruses, proteins, and cellular mechanisms invisible to earlier instruments. Today, modern cryo-electron microscopy techniques have proven invaluable for medical breakthroughs, including revealing the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein during the COVID-19 pandemic and discovering heat-sensing proteins that won a Nobel Prize.
links.page_title: Making the Electron Microscope

links.description: Sandhill Cranes raise Canada Goose gosling
links.summary: A pair of sandhill cranes in Madison, Wisconsin has adopted and is raising a Canada gosling as their own, marking only the third confirmed instance of this unusual cross-species adoption. The phenomenon appears to be occurring more frequently due to expanding populations of both species and their increased overlap in suburban wetland habitats. While the devoted crane parents are providing the gosling with care and protection, experts express concerns about its long-term survival, particularly regarding future migration when the species' different flying altitudes and timing could pose serious challenges.
links.page_title: These Sandhill Cranes Have Adopted a Canada Gosling, and Birders Have Flocked to Watch the Strange Family

links.summary:
The article presents a technique for achieving consistent classification from Large Language Models (LLMs) by combining embeddings with vector similarity search. While LLMs generate lexicographically inconsistent labels for the same content, the author discovered they remain semantically consistentâ€”allowing labels to be clustered in vector space and mapped to root categories through a disjoint set union approach.

Benchmarked results show this vectorization method significantly outperforms pure LLM classification at scale: it reduces unique labels by 80% (from 6,520 to 1,381 for 10K tweets), achieves 94% cache hit rates, and becomes 10x cheaper per classification while eventually being faster than direct LLM calls, despite initial overhead.
links.page_title: How to Get Consistent Classification From Inconsistent LLMs?

links.description: Meta Superintelligence first paper - Much more efficient RAG by doing embeddings with same tokenization as LLM
links.summary:
Meta Superintelligence Labs' first paper introduces REFRAG, a novel RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) technique that achieves 30x faster response times by encoding document chunks as compact embeddings aligned with the LLM's native embedding space, rather than converting them back to tokens. A lightweight policy network trained with reinforcement learning selectively decides which chunks should be expanded to full tokens within a computational budget, significantly reducing KV cache costs and latency while maintaining accuracy.

The paper is notable for focusing on practical, revenue-impacting system-level efficiency rather than foundational model breakthroughs, suggesting Meta's Superintelligence Labs may prioritize immediate ROI through infrastructure optimization alongside longer-term research initiatives.
links.page_title: Meta Superintelligenceâ€™s surprising first paper

links.summary: The Burrows-Wheeler Transform (BWT) is a data transformation algorithm that works by generating all rotations of a string, sorting them lexicographically, and extracting the last column of the sorted matrix. This technique is particularly useful for data compression and DNA sequence analysis because it rearranges characters in a way that groups similar characters together, making the data more compressible. The interactive example demonstrates how "banana$" is transformed through rotation and sorting to produce the BWT output.

links.summary: This study tested 11 different data formats to determine which ones LLMs understand best when processing tabular information. The research found that **Markdown-KV (key-value pairs) format significantly outperformed others at 60.7% accuracy**, while commonly-used formats like CSV and JSON performed poorly at 44.3% and 52.3% respectively. The key trade-off is that the most accurate format uses 2.7x more tokens than the most efficient format, highlighting the tension between accuracy and cost when selecting how to present data to LLMs.

links.description: F3 - the open source file format of the future
links.summary: F3 is a next-generation, open-source columnar data file format designed to address the limitations of decade-old formats like Parquet and ORC that were built for outdated hardware and workload assumptions. The key innovation of F3 is its extensibility and interoperability: it embeds WebAssembly decoders directly within each file and uses a plug-in-based architecture for encoding schemes, enabling new features to be added without breaking compatibility across different library versions. This design approach future-proofs the format against evolving hardware and workload patterns, eliminating the need to create entirely new formats every decade.
links.page_title: F3: The Open-Source Data File Format for the Future

links.description: How S3 achieves massive throughout and redundancy on slow hard drives
links.summary: AWS S3 achieves massive scale (1 PB/s throughput, 150M requests/second) on commodity hard drives by leveraging **massive parallelism and erasure coding**. Despite HDDs being physically slow and constrained to ~32 MB/s for random access, S3 overcomes these limitations by distributing data across millions of drives using a 5-of-9 erasure coding scheme, allowing reads and writes to be processed in parallel across multiple drives simultaneously. The system also optimizes sequential write patterns and distributes load across multiple front-end servers and storage nodes to prevent bottlenecks and achieve extraordinary performance at low cost.
links.page_title: How AWS S3 serves 1 petabyte per second on top of slow HDDs

HN's longevity is credited to strict community guidelines, a carefully designed ranking algorithm that prioritizes substantive content over engagement metrics, and tireless human moderation that enforces civil discourse and intellectual rigor across diverse topics from startups to science to humanities.

links.summary: The author created a Note Codes plugin for Obsidian that assigns unique 4-character codes to every note in a vault, allowing users to quickly reference notes from external sources like handwritten notes or other applications. The codes are generated using SHA-256 hashing and Crockford's Base32 encoding, with a protocol handler (`obsidian://note-codes/`) enabling easy note access. However, the plugin has two limitations: note codes change when notes are renamed, and there's a potential for code collisions due to the birthday paradox, though the author acknowledges these are acceptable trade-offs for keeping codes vault-independent and simple.
links.page_title: Obsidian Note Codes â€“ ezhik.jp

links.summary: This webpage showcases "Knitted Anatomy," a creative project that uses knitting and crochet to create educational models of the cardiovascular system. The collection includes detailed textile representations of the heart, aorta, arteries, and related structures, with pieces depicting complex conditions like aortic aneurysms and demonstrating blood flow pathways through the body. The project combines artistic craftsmanship with anatomical accuracy to visualize how blood circulates through different organs and body regions.
links.page_title: Cardiovascular system | Knitted Anatomy

links.summary: The Lean Focused Research Organization (FRO) is dedicated to advancing Lean, a formal mathematics language, through innovative research and community collaboration. Their five-year mission focuses on improving Lean's scalability, usability, proof automation, and documentation while expanding its applications across mathematics, software verification, AI research, and education. The organization aims to build a diverse, sustainable ecosystem that makes Lean an essential tool for researchers, developers, and students worldwide.
links.page_title: FRO â€” Lean Lang

The author contends that Google tacitly permits downloaders because they benefit YouTube's dominance, but deliberately makes them inconvenient and has historically pressured websites (through ad revenue threats) to avoid discussing themâ€”a practice the author criticizes as censorship motivated by corporate interests.

links.summary: RMCP is an R-based Model Context Protocol (MCP) server that enables AI assistants like Claude to perform sophisticated statistical analysis through natural conversation. It provides 52 statistical analysis tools across 11 categories, leveraging 429 R packages for tasks including regression analysis, machine learning, time series forecasting, and data visualization. The tool can be easily installed via pip and integrated with Claude Desktop or web applications, allowing users to request complex analyses like ROI calculations, economic modeling, and customer segmentation simply by asking in plain English.

links.description: Ants that lay eggs that hatch into another species
links.summary: Iberian harvester ant queens possess a remarkable biological anomaly: they can lay eggs that hatch into an entirely different species, the builder harvester ant. The queens mate with males of the other species, store their sperm, and then use it to fertilize eggs while removing their own genetic material, effectively creating clones of the other speciesâ€”a phenomenon scientists have termed "xenoparity." This discovery challenges the fundamental biological definition of a species and suggests a mutually beneficial coevolutionary relationship where the Iberian harvester ants gain additional workers while spreading the builder harvester ant population across southern Europe.
links.page_title: These Ant Queens Seem to Defy Biology: They Lay Eggs That Hatch Into Another Species

links.summary: Stephen Wolfram explores the computational theory and behavior of lambda functionsâ€”abstract computational constructs originating from Alonzo Church's work in the 1930s. The article examines how lambdas operate through beta reduction (substituting arguments into function bodies), discusses notation systems like de Bruijn indices to avoid variable naming issues, and reveals that despite their simplicity, lambdas exhibit rich and complex computational behavior. Wolfram emphasizes that lambdas have significant applications in practical computing while also presenting interesting mathematical properties, including the Church-Rosser property that guarantees unique evaluation results.
links.page_title: The Ruliology of Lambdasâ€”Stephen Wolfram Writings

links.description: The US has the rare minerals it needs
links.summary: A new Colorado School of Mines study published in *Science* reveals that the U.S. already produces all the critical minerals it needs domestically, but they are being discarded as mining waste rather than recovered. Researchers found that of 70 analyzed elements, recovering even small percentages (often less than 1-10%) of byproducts from existing U.S. mines could eliminate the need to import most critical minerals like cobalt, lithium, and rare earth elements, while also reducing environmental waste. The main challenge is making mineral recovery economically feasible, which requires additional research, technological development, and supportive government policies to incentivize mining operators to invest in recovery infrastructure.
links.page_title: U.S. already has the critical minerals it needs â€“ but they're being thrown away, new analysis shows | Colorado School of Mines | Newsroom

links.summary: "Gemini and Mercury Remastered" is a visually stunning book by Andy Saunders that showcases restored photographs from the early Mercury and Gemini space missions of the 1960s, revealing previously unseen details of these pivotal moments in human space exploration. The book serves as a prequel to "Apollo Remastered" and tells the dramatic stories of astronauts who conducted critical experiments and took iconic images of Earth while testing the feasibility of long-duration spaceflight. Featuring endorsements from notable figures like Tom Hanks, Jim Lovell, and Gene Kranz, the book celebrates the visionary achievements and challenges of the pioneers who laid the groundwork for the Apollo Moon landings.
links.page_title: About The Book â€” APOLLO REMASTERED

links.summary: The Socratic Journal Method is a simple yet effective journaling approach that treats writing as a dialogue with yourself rather than a monologue, using self-directed questions and answers to overcome the blank-page anxiety that derails most traditional journaling attempts. Backed by psychological research showing journaling reduces stress and improves mental clarity, this method works by combining upfront reflection on meaningful questions with free-flowing, uncensored answers. The author emphasizes that success depends less on fancy tools (paper, digital, or audio all work) and more on consistency and finding a format you'll actually use, offering a sustainable alternative to journaling methods that feel like chores.
links.page_title: The Socratic Journal Method: A Simple Journaling Method That Actually Works

links.summary: This blog post explores how musical evolution mirrors biological evolution by presenting interactive tools that simulate these processes. The author created a "melody breeder" where melodies compete and evolve based on user selection, and sonified Conway's Game of Life to demonstrate how simple rules generate complex patternsâ€”drawing parallels between biological systems, musical development, and cultural trends like viral phenomena. The core insight is that patterns replicate, adapt, and survive across domains (genes, memes, music, and viral trends) according to universal evolutionary principles.
links.page_title: A Digital Darwin Adventure with Mating Melodies

links.summary: PostHog redesigned its website to function like an operating system, allowing users to multitask by opening multiple windows, articles, and demos simultaneously instead of relying on traditional single-page scrolling. The design addresses common frustrations with technical websitesâ€”such as opening numerous indistinguishable tabsâ€”by implementing features like window snapping, keyboard shortcuts, and a file explorer-style interface. While unconventional and initially jarring, this innovative approach improves content consumption and engagement while maintaining technical scalability through JSON-based content management and unified customer databases.

links.description: Using Claude Code to upgrade a Linux kernel driver
links.summary: Dmitry Brant successfully modernized a 25-year-old Linux kernel driver (ftape) for reading legacy QIC-80 tape cartridges by collaborating with Claude Code AI, completing the upgrade from kernel version 2.4 to version 6.8 over two evenings. While Claude efficiently identified and replaced deprecated kernel functions, created a standalone build system, and debugged hardware communication issues through iterative analysis of system logs, the author emphasizes that success required prior kernel development knowledge and active human oversight rather than fully autonomous AI work. The experience demonstrates the value of treating AI coding assistants as collaborative junior engineers that require clear guidance, domain-specific prompts, and human judgment to deliver working results.
links.page_title: Using Claude Code to modernize a 25-year-old kernel driver â€“ Dmitry Brant

It offers multiple search modes including semantic search (understanding concepts like "error handling" to find try/catch blocks), traditional regex grep, and hybrid search combining both approaches, with features like an interactive TUI, automatic indexing, MCP server integration for AI clients like Claude, and drop-in compatibility with standard grep commands.

The core insight is that **AI coding works best with structure**â€”Claude shifts developer focus from writing boilerplate to higher-value work like architecture and design, while frameworks ensure consistent, traceable, and verifiable output.

links.description: Making my handwriting into a font
links.summary: The author created a custom handwriting font for their personal website to make it more unique and personal rather than generic. After struggling with open-source tools like FontForge and Inkscape due to their poor user interfaces, they switched to Calligraphr, a paid web-based service that works by scanning handwritten letter templates and automatically converting them into a font file. Through iterative refinement using Calligraphr's user-friendly tools to adjust letter spacing, baseline alignment, and add custom ligatures, they successfully created a personalized handwriting font that enhances their website's character.
links.page_title: Making a font of my handwriting Â· Chameth.com

links.summary: Fil's Unbelievable Garbage Collector (FUGC) is a sophisticated parallel, concurrent garbage collection system used by the Fil-C runtime that minimizes pause times through innovative techniques like soft handshakes and grey-stack marking, eliminating the need for global stop-the-world pauses. FUGC combines features from multiple GC approachesâ€”including Dijkstra barriers, on-the-fly marking, and non-moving object managementâ€”to achieve fast, accurate memory reclamation with only a simple store barrier and minimal overhead. The collector is designed to be practical for multi-threaded programs while maintaining precise pointer tracking and achieving sweep times of less than 5% of total collection time through SIMD-optimized algorithms.
links.page_title: Fil's Unbelievable Garbage Collector

links.summary: Lit is a lightweight (5KB) JavaScript library for building simple, fast web components that work across any framework or platform. Built on web standards, Lit provides reactivity, declarative templates, and scoped styling while minimizing boilerplate code. Recently joining the OpenJS Foundation, Lit enables developers to create shareable, interoperable components ideal for design systems, progressive enhancement, and maintainable applications without vendor lock-in.
links.page_title: Lit

links.description: Data engineering and software engineering are converging
links.summary: Data engineering and software engineering are converging as real-time analytics and AI-powered features become central to modern applications. The article identifies a gap in both user experience (demanding sub-second query performance) and developer experience (requiring modern software development workflows), which ClickHouse addresses through performance and scalability. MooseStack, an open-source toolkit, bridges this gap by providing data engineers and software engineers with modern development practices inspired by web frameworksâ€”including git-native workflows, local-first development, native programming languages, and CI/CD integration.
links.page_title: Data engineering and software engineering are converging

links.description: Japan opens first osmotic power generation plant
links.summary: Japan has opened its first osmotic power plant in Fukuoka, the second of its kind globally, which generates electricity by harnessing the natural process of osmosisâ€”where freshwater flows across a semipermeable membrane toward saltwater, creating pressure that powers a turbine. The facility is expected to produce approximately 880,000 kilowatt hours annually, enough to power about 220 households and support the city's desalination operations. While osmotic power is still an emerging technology with challenges around energy loss during pumping and membrane friction, it offers a significant advantage over other renewables by providing consistent, 24/7 energy generation regardless of weather conditions.
links.page_title: Japan has opened its first osmotic power plant â€“ so what is it and how does it work? | Japan | The Guardian

The project highlights the potential of AI automation to handle repetitive development tasks at scale without human intervention. This showcases a significant advancement in autonomous software development capabilities.

links.summary: Researchers hunting for "busy beaver numbers"â€”which measure the longest-running simple computer programs with a given number of rulesâ€”have discovered that the sixth busy beaver number (BB(6)) is incomprehensibly larger than previously thought. The number is so vast that it would be physically impossible to write it down even if you carved a digit into every atom in the universe. This breakthrough comes from the Busy Beaver Challenge, an online community of amateur and professional mathematicians, and reveals just how quickly the complexity of computational problems escalates as parameters increase.
links.page_title: Busy Beaver Hunters Reach Numbers That Overwhelm Ordinary Math | Quanta Magazine

links.description: SmallJS - Smalltalk 80 in the browser for web apps
links.summary:
# SmallJS Summary

SmallJS is a free, open-source implementation of Smalltalk-80 that compiles to JavaScript for use in modern browsers and Node.js environments. It offers developers a more elegant alternative to JavaScript with full object-oriented customization, file-based development (compatible with VS Code), and automatic importing of only the necessary base libraries. The platform supports both front-end and back-end development with pre-encapsulated libraries for browsers and Node.js, and is currently in version 2.0 development.
links.page_title: SmallJS - Home

links.description: OKLCH colors - A more consistent and scalable color model
links.summary: OKLCH is a perceptually uniform color model that makes creating consistent color palettes much easier than traditional models like RGB or HSL. Unlike other color models, OKLCH allows designers to maintain consistent brightness and hue across different color variations by simply adjusting individual values (Lightness, Chroma, and Hue), and it produces smoother gradients without muddy midpoints. With broad modern browser support and the ability to access wider color gamuts like Display-P3, OKLCH is becoming the preferred choice for scalable, predictable color management in web design.
links.page_title: What are OKLCH colors?

links.summary: This website offers a semester-long curriculum (15 classes) designed around the TV series *Halt and Catch Fire* to help small groups explore technology history through a "watching club" format. Each class includes curated materials such as episode summaries, discussion prompts, readings, and reflective exercises using RFCs and browser-based computer emulation to deepen understanding of 1980s-1990s tech history. The flexible structure allows groups to engage with content at their own pace, with episode watching encouraged but not required.

links.description: Prompt ideas from Claude Code guide
links.summary: Claude Code stands out as an exceptionally user-friendly AI agent because it prioritizes simplicity and debuggability over complexity, using a single main control loop, smaller models for most tasks, and carefully crafted prompts with extensive examples and heuristics. The article provides a practical guide for building similarly delightful LLM agents, emphasizing key principles like keeping systems simple, using context files (claude.md) for user preferences, designing high-level tools, and resisting the temptation to over-engineer with multi-agent systems or complex RAG algorithms. The main takeaway is that architectural simplicity, combined with strategic use of smaller models (like Claude 3.5 Haiku) and well-structured prompts with XML tags and examples, creates a better user experience than more complicated approaches.
links.page_title: Minusx | What makes Claude Code so damn good (and how to recreate that magic in your agent)!?

links.summary: The author argues that achieving AGI requires shifting focus from scaling larger language models to building engineered systems that integrate specialized components like context management, persistent memory, deterministic workflows, and modular models. Current LLMs have hit diminishing returns and fundamental limitations in reasoning and context retention that bigger models alone cannot solve. AGI is fundamentally a distributed systems engineering problem requiring infrastructure that combines multiple specialized AI components with reliable orchestration, rather than a machine learning breakthrough.
links.page_title: AGI is an Engineering Problem | Vinci Rufus

links.description: Lappverk for maintaining patches on git
links.summary: This article announces **Lappverk**, a new tool for maintaining patches on Git that solves the problem of managing long-lived, custom modifications to other people's software. The author argues that while Git excels at forward-moving history, it struggles with the needs of maintaining isolated patches that must be rebased and tracked over yearsâ€”a challenge that existing tools like Quilt handle awkwardly. Lappverk proposes using Git's native `format-patch` and `am` commands to import and export patches, giving developers a familiar Git workflow while keeping patches as versionable text files.
links.page_title: Modifying Other People's Software | natkr's ramblings

links.description: Using Python decorators as a DSL
links.summary: This article explores how Python decorators like `@jit` enable using Python as a Domain-Specific Language (DSL) in machine learning libraries such as JAX and Triton. Rather than executing decorated functions normally through the Python interpreter, these libraries parse the function's code into an intermediate representation and compile it (often to LLVM IR) for specialized execution, such as on GPUs. The author provides educational implementations of AST-based JIT decorators that demonstrate the translation pipeline from Python source code to compiled, optimized machine code, with Triton serving as a real-world case study of this pattern.
links.page_title: Decorator JITs - Python as a DSL - Eli Bendersky's website

links.summary: This is the archives page of Eli Bendersky's technical blog, which contains over 2,000 posts spanning from 2003 to 2025. The site features articles on diverse programming and computer science topics including Python, Go, C++, machine learning, compilers, and algorithms, with popular posts covering subjects like Bloom filters, consistent hashing, and the Softmax function. Users can browse content by year, by specific tags, or access RSS feeds for the entire blog or individual topics.
links.page_title: Archives - Eli Bendersky's website

links.summary: This article demonstrates how to reimplement the word2vec modelâ€”a foundational 2013 machine learning technique for creating semantic word embeddingsâ€”using the JAX framework. The post explains how embeddings convert words into meaningful dense vectors for neural networks, describes the CBOW (Continuous Bag Of Words) architecture that predicts center words from context, and provides a clean JAX implementation with training code using the text8 dataset. Key takeaways include understanding embeddings as the bridge between symbolic words and semantic vector representations, and seeing how the relatively simple forward pass and loss computation can be efficiently implemented in modern JAX.
links.page_title: Reproducing word2vec with JAX - Eli Bendersky's website

links.summary: This article explains **unification**, a fundamental algorithm in logic and computer science that automatically solves equations between symbolic terms. The author provides a complete Python implementation of the basic unification algorithm, starting with simpler pattern matching concepts and progressing to general unification where both terms can contain variables. Key takeaways include understanding how unification finds variable substitutions to make terms equivalent, the importance of finding the "most general unifier" (mgu), and critical implementation details like the occurs check to prevent infinite self-referential bindings.
links.page_title: Unification - Eli Bendersky's website

links.title: Derivatives, Gradients, Jacobians and Hessians â€“ OhÂ My!
links.summary: This article explains the hierarchical relationship between four fundamental calculus concepts used in optimization and computer graphics. **Derivatives** measure how functions change and are used in optimization methods like gradient descent; **gradients** extend this to multivariable functions as vectors of partial derivatives that point in the steepest direction; **Jacobian matrices** combine multiple gradients to describe how multidimensional spaces are warped; and **Hessian matrices** contain second-order partial derivatives to reveal function curvature, enabling more efficient optimization. Each concept builds upon the previous one, with practical applications ranging from finding function minima to rendering and machine learning.
links.page_title: Derivatives, Gradients, Jacobians and Hessians â€“ Oh My! Â« The blog at the bottom of the sea

links.summary: Roland Reisley, 101 years old, is the last living original client of Frank Lloyd Wright and has resided in his architect-designed home in Pleasantville, New York for over 73 years. The house, part of the mid-century modern Usonian community Wright envisioned, features his signature organic architecture including a hexagonal design, natural materials, and seamless integration with nature. Though the project initially cost far more than budgeted and Wright was known for being difficult, Reisley formed a lasting friendship with the renowned architect, who made collaborative design choices to accommodate the family's needs.

links.description: A new active learning method for curating high-quality data that reduces training data requirements for fine-tuning LLMs by orders of magnitude.
links.summary: Google researchers developed a new active learning method that reduces training data requirements for fine-tuning large language models by up to 10,000x while improving model alignment with human experts. The approach uses a scalable curation process that iteratively identifies the most informative and ambiguous examples for expert annotationâ€”specifically targeting overlapping decision boundaries where the model is most confusedâ€”rather than requiring massive labeled datasets. In experiments on content moderation tasks, the method achieved significant data reduction (from 100,000 to under 500 examples) while maintaining or improving quality, with larger models showing even greater improvements.
links.page_title: Achieving 10,000x training data reduction with high-fidelity labels

links.summary: Google has introduced a new feature in the Gemini app that generates personalized, illustrated storybooks with AI-created artwork and narration. Users can describe any story idea, and Gemini will produce a 10-page book in over 45 different artistic styles and languages, with the option to incorporate personal photos and files for a custom touch. The feature is designed for various use cases, such as explaining complex topics to children, teaching lessons, or transforming family memories into engaging stories.

links.summary: A design document is a technical report meant to convince readers that a proposed design is optimal given specific constraints and trade-offs. The key to writing effective design documents is organizing information clearly so readers never feel surprised, anticipating objections preemptively, and ruthlessly editing for brevityâ€”treating the document like a logical proof where each paragraph builds obviously from the previous one. Success requires significant practice and a commitment to clarity over cleverness, using techniques like short paragraphs with single main ideas and appendices for complex supporting details.
links.page_title: Writing a good design document

links.summary: Oaklisp is an object-oriented dialect of Scheme that combines standard Lisp syntax with features like macros, first-class types, multiple inheritance, and packages. This portable implementation compiles Oaklisp source code into bytecode for execution on an included virtual machine. The project includes comprehensive academic documentation and can be built following the provided BUILD.md instructions.
links.page_title: GitHub - barak/oaklisp: An object-oriented dialect of Scheme

links.summary: Steph Ango recommends creating individual "ramblings" channels for remote team members as a way to share thoughts and ideas without cluttering main chat channels. These personal channels function like lightweight journals where team members post updates 1-3 times weekly about projects, ideas, and musings, with others able to reply but not start new conversations. At Obsidian, ramblings have proven effective for maintaining social cohesion and generating creative solutions while minimizing interruptions and preserving deep focus time.
links.page_title: If you're remote, ramble â€” Steph Ango

links.description: langextract - Extract structured information from text using LLM
links.summary: LangExtract is a Python library by Google that extracts structured information from unstructured text using LLMs while maintaining precise source grounding and providing interactive visualization. Key features include mapping extractions to exact locations in source text, enforcing consistent output schemas, handling long documents efficiently, and supporting multiple LLM providers (Google Gemini, OpenAI, local models via Ollama). The library is designed to work across any domain with just a few examples, requiring no model fine-tuning, and can process everything from clinical notes to full novels with interactive HTML visualization for review.
links.page_title: GitHub - google/langextract: A Python library for extracting structured information from unstructured text using LLMs with precise source grounding and interactive visualization.

links.summary: The article examines whether "the bitter lesson"â€”the principle that general computational methods ultimately outperform human-designed AI systemsâ€”has limits. While the author initially accepts this lesson (which aligns with historical trends in chess, Go, and speech recognition), he raises practical objections to applying it in business settings: organizations struggle to define clear objectives and gather quality data resistant to gaming, and recent chess developments show that Stockfish defeated pure deep learning by combining smaller, purpose-built models with efficient search algorithms rather than simply scaling computation. The key takeaway is that the bitter lesson may not universally apply when objectives are ambiguous, data is limited, or hybrid approaches prove more effective than raw computational scaling.
links.page_title: Does the Bitter Lesson Have Limits?

links.summary: This article introduces **Lean**, a programming language designed to formalize mathematics by treating proofs as code that can be verified, composed, and shared. The author explains Lean's core concepts through practical examples, starting with simple reflexivity proofs (like proving 2 = 2) and progressing to how axioms workâ€”demonstrating that adding a false axiom (like "2 = 3") allows mathematicians to prove anything, mirroring historical mathematical crises like the contradictions discovered in early 20th-century set theory. The key takeaway is that Lean enables rigorous, computer-verifiable mathematics, but highlights how critical it is to choose correct axioms as a foundation.
links.page_title: The Math Is Haunted â€” overreacted

links.description: Google is bullish on their Gemini embedding models

Beyond traditional uses like semantic search and RAG, developers are leveraging these embeddings for "context engineering" to provide AI agents with comprehensive operational context by efficiently identifying and integrating critical information into a model's working memory. Early implementations, such as Box's use of the model for document analysis, demonstrate strong performance improvements, with Gemini Embedding achieving over 81% accuracy in finding correct answers and outperforming competing models by 3.6% in recall.
links.page_title:
Gemini Embedding: Powering RAG and context engineering

links.description: The rise and fall of the Hanseatic League
links.summary: The Hanseatic League was a medieval coalition of German merchant cities that built Northern Europe's first long-distance trade network without formal corporate structures or a central government, lasting nearly 500 years. The League emerged after Europe's agricultural revolution (around 900 AD) improved crop yields and enabled the growth of towns and trade, while innovations in shipbuilding and warmer climate made sea routes more navigable. Though ultimately weakened by internal factionalism and defection, the Hansa's impact was enduringâ€”it secured trade routes and significantly increased European state capacity to support commerce.
links.page_title: The rise and fall of the Hanseatic League - Works in Progress Magazine

links.summary: ImageToDrawio.com is an AI-powered online tool that converts images of diagrams (screenshots, photos, hand-drawn sketches) into editable Draw.io format files. The service operates on a simple pay-per-conversion model, offering 3 free trials without login, and ensures user privacy by deleting uploaded images after processing. Key use cases include recovering lost diagram source files, digitizing whiteboard sketches, customizing diagrams found online, and modernizing legacy documentation.
links.page_title: #1 Image to Draw.io Converter - Transform Screenshots & Diagrams in 1 minute

links.summary: Daniele Procida explores the German word "Gegenstand" (object/thing, literally "stand-against") to argue why high-quality documentation and information architecture still matter in an age of AI and customized answers. He contends that objects, knowledge, and information must maintain their own integrity and resistanceâ€”they shouldn't be over-fitted to individual desiresâ€”because this resistance is what gives us structure, shared understanding, and meaningful encounters with reality. Just as good design requires a balance between fit and resistance, good documentation should resist the temptation to be entirely tailored and instead maintain its own rational organization, which paradoxically leads to richer, more unexpected learning experiences.
links.page_title: My favourite German word - Daniele Procida

links.summary: The `uv` tool simplifies running Python scripts by automatically managing virtual environments and dependencies without manual setup. Scripts can be executed with `uv run`, with dependencies declared either via command-line flags (e.g., `--with`), inline metadata at the top of the script file, or project configuration files. Key features include support for Python version selection, dependency locking for reproducibility, shebang support for executable scripts, and alternative package index configuration.
links.page_title: Running scripts | uv

links.description: Slow motion is what modernity looks like as it is dying
links.summary: Slow motion has evolved from a rare and underutilized filmmaking technique into cinema's most dominant special effect, particularly since the late 1960s when *Bonnie and Clyde* popularized its use for depicting violence and trauma. According to cultural scholar Mark Goble's new book, slow motion's ubiquity reflects modern experienceâ€”capturing time as "variously uneven, punctuated and accelerated, dragging and expanding, beautiful, traumatic, endless, and commodified." Beyond film, slow motion has become a cultural vocabulary for articulating traumatic experiences, suggesting that our collective sense of being stuck in an endless, inescapable moment may explain why audiences continue to find this effect so resonant today.
links.page_title: How Slow Motion Became Cinemaâ€™s Dominant Special Effect | The New Republic

links.description: Writing a book in Markdown (with epub, PDF, HTML output)
links.summary: This article details the author's process for writing and self-publishing a technical book using Markdown as the source format. The author developed scripts using Pandoc and related tools to generate professional PDF, EPUB, HTML, and MOBI outputs from Markdown files, including features like code syntax highlighting, table of contents, and cross-references. Key takeaways include the project structure (organizing chapters in numbered Markdown files), the tech stack used (Pandoc, pandoc-crossref, Eisvogel LaTeX template), and important gotchas like format-specific rendering issues with math equations and smart typography features.
links.page_title: Write a Book with Markdown

links.summary: SIOF (Scheme In One File) is a minimal, portable R7RS Scheme interpreter that compiles from a single C source file with no external dependencies, making it easy to build and deploy across different platforms. While largely R7RS-small compatible, it has some limitations such as 30-bit fixnums, no Unicode support, and no support for bignums or complex numbers, but it includes essential Scheme features like garbage collection, proper tail recursion, and a hygienic macro system. The interpreter can be compiled with standard C compilers and offers precompiled binaries for various platforms, with optional optimization flags available for improved performance.
links.page_title: GitHub - false-schemers/siof: SIOF (Scheme In One File) is a minimal interpreter for R7RS Scheme

links.summary: This article examines the architectural evolution of large language models (LLMs) from GPT-2 to modern models like DeepSeek V3 and Llama 4, revealing that despite superficial refinements, the core transformer structure remains largely unchanged since 2019. The author focuses specifically on two key efficiency innovations in DeepSeek V3: Multi-Head Latent Attention (MLA), which compresses key-value tensors to reduce memory usage while improving performance, and Mixture-of-Experts (MoE), which replaces single feedforward layers with multiple expert modules activated selectively per token to increase model capacity without proportionally increasing computational cost.
links.page_title: The Big LLM Architecture Comparison

links.description: New asynch tools may change DB architectures
links.summary: The author explores how Linux's **io_uring** can dramatically improve database performance by enabling truly asynchronous I/O operations, but discovers this creates durability challenges. To solve this, they implement a **dual write-ahead log (WAL) design** that separates intent records (what operations to perform) from completion records (confirmation of success), allowing async writes while maintaining consistency guarantees. This approach achieves a 10x throughput improvement through intelligent batching, demonstrating that modern async I/O tools could fundamentally reshape database architectures.
links.page_title: Async I/O on Linux and durability

links.description: An artificially complex XML schema is a lock-in tool
links.summary: The document format XML schema should prioritize simplicity and accessibility, but Microsoft 365 deliberately uses an artificially complex XML schema as a vendor lock-in strategy to prevent competitors from creating compatible solutions. This unnecessary complexityâ€”characterized by deeply nested tags, excessive abstraction, and convoluted naming conventionsâ€”creates barriers for developers while remaining invisible to end users, ultimately trapping customers into Microsoft's ecosystem much like a railway system with simple tracks but deliberately incomprehensible train controls. The author argues that millions of users have failed to critically examine these proprietary technologies, allowing Microsoft to strengthen its monopoly through increasingly sophisticated lock-in tactics.
links.page_title: An artificially complex XML schema as a lock-in tool - TDF Community Blog

links.description: *Silence is a Commons* by Ivan Illich
links.summary: Ivan Illich argues that electronic communication devices are enclosing "silence" as a commonsâ€”much like the historical enclosure of pastures and streetsâ€”by forcing people to communicate on machine terms and filtering out behaviors that don't fit computational logic. He advocates for a political ecology approach to distinguish between the "commons" (shared environmental resources essential for community subsistence) and "resources" (commodified goods for economic production), warning that modern electronic management degrades human autonomy and self-governance. Illich calls for societies, particularly Japan, to adopt self-limitation in communication technology to preserve democratic control and prevent the colonization of human behavior by machines.
links.page_title: Silence is a Commons by Ivan Illich

links.description: How can this article be applied to creeping asynchrony in our genai code base?
links.summary:
This article argues that **asynchrony and concurrency are distinct concepts** that are often conflated in programming. Asynchrony refers to tasks running out of order while remaining correct (like saving two independent files), while concurrency requires actual simultaneous progress (like a server accepting connections while a client connects). The author proposes that this distinction matters because conflating them has led to inefficient language ecosystems where async code becomes "viral," forcing library users into async-only workflows.

**Key takeaway for your GenAI codebase:** Rather than making asynchronous patterns mandatory throughout your codebase, you could design libraries and utilities that support *asynchrony without requiring concurrency*, allowing synchronous code to remain viable while still enabling concurrent execution when needed. This would reduce unnecessary complexity and avoid forcing all dependencies into an async model.
links.page_title: Asynchrony is not Concurrency | Loris Cro's Blog

links.summary: This blog post provides a curated guide for staying informed about AI progress through a balanced information pipeline. The author emphasizes the importance of building a solid understanding of AI to avoid common pitfallsâ€”either dismissing it as hype or overestimating its capabilitiesâ€”by following trustworthy sources and staying close to primary sources rather than sensationalized media coverage. The recommended resources include technical experts like Simon Willison and Andrej Karpathy, official announcements from major AI labs (OpenAI, Google DeepMind, Anthropic), and experienced AI engineers who share practical insights on building and evaluating AI systems.
links.page_title: How I keep up with AI progress - nilenso blog

links.description: Terragon - Isolated sandboxes for agent coding
links.summary: Terragon is a platform that delegates coding tasks to AI agents running in isolated cloud sandboxes, allowing developers to focus on higher-priority work. Users can describe tasks via GitHub integration, and the AI agents automatically complete them and open pull requests for review, supporting multiple AI models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini, etc.) and integrations with tools like GitHub, Slack, and Linear. **Note:** The service is shutting down on February 9th, 2026.
links.page_title: Terragon - Delegate coding tasks to AI background agents

links.summary: The author shares their experience using Claude Code with a new tool called Terragon to manage multiple AI coding agents in the cloud. Key takeaways include: Claude Max ($200/month) provides cost-effective unlimited access to Claude Code, which shifts focus from task optimization to maximizing AI workload; Terragon solves the complexity of running parallel agents by handling environment management, allowing the author to process ~30 tasks daily while focusing locally on review and testing. The hybrid workflow proves most effective for exploration tasks, bug investigation, boilerplate work, and one-shot code cleanup, while requiring disciplined task management to avoid context-switching pitfalls.
links.page_title: Claude Code Unleashed

links.description: How does homomorphic encryption work in an AI scenario where text is involved?
links.summary: Fully Homomorphic Encryption (FHE) enables computation on encrypted data without decryption, allowing services like Google or OpenAI to process user queries and return results while never accessing the plaintext information. Though currently 1,000-10,000x slower than plaintext operations, FHE has been improving 8x faster annually and is approaching practical viability for encrypted cloud computing and AI inference, potentially transforming the internet from "spy by default" to "privacy by default." The technology uses lattice-based cryptography, which is believed to be quantum-resistant, making it a foundational approach to achieving true end-to-end privacy where data remains encrypted during storage, transit, and processing.
links.page_title: Fully Homomorphic Encryption and the Dawn of A Truly Private Internet

links.summary: This blog post teaches readers how to manually create Git repositories from scratch by understanding Git's internal architecture, rather than using standard commands like `git init`. The author emphasizes Git's elegant design, particularly its use of Content Addressable Storage (CAS), where objects are stored and identified by SHA-1 hashes of their contents rather than filenames. By building a repository by handâ€”creating the `.git` directory structure, configuration files, and manually crafting commit objectsâ€”readers gain deeper insight into how Git works under the hood.

links.summary: DNS over HTTPS (DoH) is an encryption protocol that protects DNS queries and responses by transmitting them through HTTPS on port 443, preventing attackers from forging or altering DNS traffic. By camouflaging DNS queries within standard HTTPS traffic, DoH enhances privacy and security while maintaining compatibility with existing internet infrastructure. Cloudflare's 1.1.1.1 service offers DoH implementation options for browsers, clients, and API requests.
