The Django Software Foundation is launching worldwide celebrations throughout 2025 and has set a fundraising goal to secure 200 new donors contributing $20 or more, with a target of at least 20 monthly donors to support the project's continued development. The framework aims to remain thriving for decades to come with continued releases, ecosystem growth, and community support.
links.page_title: Happy 20th birthday Django! | Weblog | Django

links.summary: Arial has become ubiquitous in modern computing not because of its design quality, but because Microsoft bundled it with Windows as a cheaper alternative to the licensed Helvetica font. Created by Monotype as a Helvetica substitute for PostScript clones in the late 1980s, Arial deliberately mimics Helvetica's proportions while claiming to be an original designâ€”a deceptive approach that professionals view as inferior imitation. Despite its pervasiveness among casual users, designers regard Arial with disdain as a "low-end" font that succeeded through corporate distribution rather than merit.
links.page_title: The Scourge of Arial

links.description: The 100th anniversary of the Heisenberg to Pauli letter on the tru structure of the Hydrogen atom
links.summary: On July 9, 1925, Werner Heisenberg sent a letter to Wolfgang Pauli outlining revolutionary ideas that laid the foundation for modern quantum mechanics, marking the birth of quantum theory as we know it today. Heisenberg's key breakthrough was abandoning the classical model of atoms as planetary systems with orbiting electrons, instead developing a framework based purely on observable experimental dataâ€”an approach that eventually evolved into matrix mechanics with contributions from Born, Jordan, and Pauli himself. Today, 100 years later, quantum mechanics underpins the Standard Model of particle physics and continues to drive innovations in quantum sensors and computing, though fundamental questions about the theory's true meaning remain unresolved.
links.page_title: A century of quantum mechanics | CERN

links.description: Why Trumpâ€™s trade threats arenâ€™t working
links.summary: Trump's trade threats through tariffs are largely failing to achieve meaningful concessions from other countries, despite the US consumer market's enormous economic power. The article identifies three key reasons: (1) trading partners lack confidence that tariff removals are permanent, since the administration can simply reimpose them arbitrarily without legal constraints; (2) newly invented tariffs lack negotiating value compared to long-established trade policies, as they're painless for the US to remove; and (3) Trump's confrontational rhetoric has undermined the political space foreign leaders need to make unpopular trade deals domestically. While Trump successfully raised tariffs and got countries to the negotiating table, actual policy changes have been minimal and largely superficial.
links.page_title: Trumpâ€™s Trade Threats: Why Isn't This Working? | ExplainTrade

links.summary: The LLM Inference Handbook is a comprehensive technical resource that consolidates fragmented knowledge about LLM inference into one centralized guide, covering core concepts, performance metrics, optimization techniques, and production deployment patterns. Designed for engineers deploying and operating LLMs in production, it provides practical, field-tested guidance focused on making LLM inference faster, cheaper, and more reliable rather than covering edge cases. The handbook is continuously updated with the latest best practices and welcomes community contributions to stay current with the rapidly evolving field.
links.page_title: LLM Inference Handbook

It prioritizes privacy by running AI models locally and offers key features like AI agent automation, split-view access to ChatGPT/Claude/Gemini, MCP server integrations, and works as a productivity tool across macOS, Windows, and Linux. As a Chromium-based browser, it supports Chrome extensions and positions itself as a privacy-focused alternative to traditional browsers like Chrome, designed for the AI era.
links.page_title: BrowserOS - Open-Source AI Browser | Privacy-First Alternative to Perplexity Comet

links.summary: DCHP-3 is a dictionary that catalogs Canadian English words and meanings using a systematic typology of six categories of "Canadianisms"â€”ranging from words originating in Canada (Type 1) to preserved archaic terms (Type 2) to culturally significant vocabulary (Type 4). Each entry includes quotations from Canadian sources, frequency charts comparing Canadian usage to other English-speaking regions, and detailed editorial information to help users understand how and why specific words are classified as distinctly Canadian. The resource also tracks "memorial" terms related to Canada's darker historical aspects, offering a comprehensive linguistic record of Canadian identity and expression.
links.page_title: DCHP-3

links.title: https://mcp-b.ai
links.description: MCP-B - Tool automation in the browser
links.summary:
# MCP-B Summary

MCP-B (Model Context Protocol for the Browser) enables AI assistants to directly call website functions instead of relying on screen-reading automation. By adding ~50 lines of code to a website, developers can expose structured APIs to AI assistants using the user's existing browser sessionâ€”eliminating the need for API keys, OAuth, or complex configuration. This approach delivers 10,000x performance improvements over traditional browser automation, completing tasks in milliseconds while maintaining security through existing authentication methods.
links.page_title: MCP Web | Model Context Protocol for the Browser

links.description: Most RESTful ApIS are not really RESTful
links.summary: Most APIs claiming to be "RESTful" are not actually RESTful according to Roy Fielding's original architectural definition. The key misconception is that REST merely requires using HTTP verbs and CRUD operations on resources, when Fielding actually emphasizes that true REST must be "driven by hypertext" through HATEOAS (Hypermedia as the Engine of Application State)â€”meaning clients should dynamically discover available actions through server responses rather than relying on external documentation. Without hypermedia controls to decouple clients from servers, APIs fail to achieve REST's core benefits like evolvability and maintainability.
links.page_title: Most RESTful APIs arenâ€™t really RESTful | Florian KrÃ¤mer

It is built on functional programming principles, offering features like modulation suggestions, group theoretical analysis, and pattern matching for both traditional and unconventional musical systems.

links.description: Why honey doesnâ€™t spoil when sealed
links.summary: Honey remains fresh for years when sealed due to its unique chemistry and how bees produce it. The bees remove water from nectar through enzymatic processes and wing-fanning, reducing the final water content to just 15-18%, which creates a state called "low water activity" where bacteria and fungi cannot surviveâ€”even though they would normally thrive on sugar. This combination of minimal moisture, high acidity, and limited oxygen in sealed jars makes honey remarkably resistant to spoilage, unlike other preserved foods that eventually succumb to microbial growth.
links.page_title: The chemical secrets that help keep honey fresh for so long

links.description: Pet ownership and its relationship to cognitive decline
links.summary: This longitudinal study, spanning 18 years of data from over 8,000 European adults aged 50+, found that pet ownership is associated with slower cognitive decline in executive functioning and episodic memoryâ€”key markers of healthy aging. Importantly, the protective effect varied by pet type: **dog and cat ownership showed significant benefits in slowing cognitive decline, while bird and fish ownership showed no such association**. The findings suggest that interactive pets may act as a protective factor against age-related cognitive decline, though the mechanisms likely involve increased physical activity, reduced loneliness, lower stress levels, and enhanced social interaction.

links.summary: This tribute to editor Lewis H. Lapham reflects on the author's eight years working at *Lapham's Quarterly*, the magazine he founded in 2007 as a digest of historical ideas and thought. The piece celebrates Lapham's editorial philosophyâ€”that "all good editors are pirates"â€”highlighting his meticulous work ethic, collaborative approach, and commitment to exquisite writing over hierarchy, which fundamentally shaped how the author later founded her own publication. Through vivid anecdotes of late-night literary gatherings and office culture, the author portrays Lapham as a freeing, inspiring mentor who demonstrated how to build a thriving intellectual magazine while maintaining irreverence toward the American establishment.

links.summary:
The author describes building a "personal AI factory"â€”a system of multiple AI agents (Claude, o3, Sonnet models) working in parallel to generate, verify, and improve code automatically. The key principle is to fix the *inputs* (plans, prompts, agent configurations) rather than manually patching *outputs*, so the system continuously improves itself and learns from mistakes across all future tasks.

The workflow involves o3 creating plans, Sonnet models executing them, and verification agents checking results against the original requirements. By encoding lessons back into the planning system rather than making one-off code fixes, the author has created a self-improving system that can handle increasingly complex tasks with minimal manual intervention.
links.page_title: Building a Personal AI Factory (July 2025 snapshot)

links.description: Context engineering rather than prompt engineering
links.summary: The article argues that **context engineering**â€”not prompt engineeringâ€”is becoming the critical skill for building effective AI agents. Context engineering involves strategically providing all necessary information, tools, and structured data (including instructions, conversation history, retrieved knowledge, and available functions) to enable an LLM to successfully complete tasks. The key insight is that most agent failures stem from poor context rather than model limitations, and the difference between a basic demo and a "magical" product lies in the quality and relevance of the context provided before the LLM generates a response.
links.page_title: The New Skill in AI is Not Prompting, It's Context Engineering

links.summary: Moore's Lawâ€”the observation that transistor density on chips doubles roughly every two yearsâ€”is becoming unsustainable due to escalating manufacturing costs and physical limitations. While the cost to build semiconductor fabrication plants has skyrocketed from $2-4 billion 25 years ago to over $100 billion today, the industry is simultaneously hitting hard physical barriers: conventional photoresist materials stop working below 5-10 nanometers, transistor geometry has become exponentially more complex to manufacture, and current optical techniques are approaching their theoretical limits. Without clear solutions to these compounding challenges, the industry faces an impending wall where further miniaturization may become economically and physically impossible.
links.page_title: The Unsustainability of Mooreâ€™s Law - by Charles Rosenbauer

AARP's advocacy work extends year-round at federal, state, and local levels, with the organization amplifying members' voices by surveying constituents, identifying priority issues, and mobilizing grassroots campaignsâ€”as demonstrated when over 2 million member emails to Congress successfully pressured the Social Security Administration to reverse planned service cuts. Since its founding in 1958, AARP has played a crucial role in major legislative achievements including the creation of Medicare and Medicaid, passage of the Older Americans Act, and protection of Social Security.

# miniKanren Summary

miniKanren is a family of domain-specific languages for logic programming built on a simple core of just three logical operators and one interface operator, with the name deriving from the Japanese word for "relation." It has been implemented across numerous programming languages including Scheme, Racket, Clojure, Python, JavaScript, Haskell, and many others, and is designed to be easily modified and extended with features like constraint logic programming and probabilistic inference. The project is supported by an active community with annual workshops at ICFP, a published book ("The Reasoned Schemer"), online courses, and extensive documentation including papers, tutorials, and implementations.

links.description: Sounds and music reshape brain organization in real time
links.summary: Researchers from Aarhus University and the University of Oxford have discovered that the brain dynamically reorganizes its neural networks in real time when exposed to sound, rather than simply registering it passively. Using a novel neuroimaging method called FREQ-NESS, scientists can now trace how different sound frequencies propagate through brain regions, revealing the brain's complex interplay of brainwaves. This breakthrough could revolutionize our understanding of perception, attention, consciousness, and has significant implications for brain-computer interfaces and clinical diagnostics.
links.page_title: Dancing brainwaves: How sound reshapes your brain networks in real time | ScienceDaily

links.description: Frequent reauth doesnâ€™t make you more secure
links.summary: Frequent reauthentication is counterproductive for security, as it frustrates users, increases vulnerability to phishing and MFA fatigue attacks, and doesn't actually address real remote attack vectors. Instead, organizations should implement continuous, real-time security verification through device posture checks and automatic policy updates that work silently in the background. The key to effective security is checking device possession only when needed for sensitive actions and using OS-level protections like screen locks, rather than relying on arbitrary login prompts.
links.page_title: Frequent reauth doesn't make you more secure

links.summary: The Rough-Skinned Newt of the Pacific Northwest is the world's most toxic newt, capable of killing several humans with its poisonâ€”a toxicity driven by an evolutionary arms race with garter snakes. The snakes have evolved resistance to the newt's tetrodotoxin and deliberately eat the newts to sequester their poison as defense against their own predators, forcing the newts into an impossible predicament: they must continuously evolve greater toxicity to deter predation, bear the metabolic cost of producing that toxin, and yet cannot evolve warning colors because that would make them easy prey for the snakes. This creates a deadlock where neither species can escape the cycle, leaving researchers still uncovering mysteries about regional variations in this fascinating evolutionary conflict.

links.summary: Scientists at the National Solar Observatory and New Jersey Institute of Technology developed a groundbreaking "coronal adaptive optics" system called Cona that removes atmospheric blur to produce the clearest images of the Sun's corona ever captured. The system, installed on the Goode Solar Telescope in California, uses a mirror that reshapes 2,200 times per second to compensate for Earth's atmospheric turbulence, revealing unprecedented details of solar phenomena including coronal rain strands narrower than 20 kilometers and fine-structured prominences. These high-resolution observations, published in Nature Astronomy, provide critical new insights into coronal heating, solar eruptions, and space weather that will help validate computer models of solar processes.
links.page_title: â€œRaindrops in the Sunâ€™s Coronaâ€: New Adaptive Optics Shows Stunning Details of our Starâ€™s Atmosphere - NSO - National Solar Observatory

links.title: Michael Nielsen "Lisp as the Maxwellâ€™s equations of software"
links.summary: This essay explores Alan Kay's famous comparison of Lisp to Maxwell's equations of physics, explaining how a half-page of Lisp code represents the fundamental essence of programming. The author teaches basic Lisp fundamentals and guides readers through building a functioning Lisp interpreter in Python, enabling them to understand and execute the elegant, foundational code from the original LISP 1.5 manual. By making these abstract concepts concrete and executable, the essay demonstrates why Lisp is considered a uniquely elegant and powerful expression of computational principles.

links.summary: This article explains a historical method for estimating logarithms (base 10) developed by John Napier around 1615, which leverages the principle that a number's logarithm approximates its digit count minus one. By combining this with logarithm properties and scientific notation, the method allows for calculating logarithms to arbitrary precision through iterative exponentiationâ€”a technique that Henry Briggs famously used to compute logarithms to 14 decimal places. The author provides a Python implementation demonstrating how just 10 iterations of squaring can achieve 4 digits of precision.
links.page_title: Estimating Logarithms - Niklas Oberhuber

links.summary:
# Nitrogen Triiodide Summary

Nitrogen triiodide (NIâ‚ƒ) is an extremely unstable explosive compound formed by reacting iodine with ammonium hydroxide, notable for being sensitive enough to detonate from minimal disturbances like a feather tickle or loud noise. The instability arises from steric strain caused by three large iodine atoms bonded to one side of a nitrogen atom, creating a high-energy configuration that readily collapses into nitrogen gas and iodine with a violent release of energy. Because NIâ‚ƒ is so unpredictable and will detonate uncontrollably before reaching useful quantities, it has no practical applications and poses no real terrorism threat, despite being relatively easy to synthesize.
links.page_title: Nitrogen Triiodide

links.summary: Adam Riess, a Nobel Prize-winning physicist who discovered that the universe's expansion is accelerating (leading to the theory of dark energy), has begun to doubt the very "standard model of cosmology" his work helped establish. In recent years, Riess has observed a persistent discrepancy called the "Hubble tension"â€”measurements of the universe's current expansion rate don't match predictions based on observations of the early universeâ€”which suggests that the standard cosmological model may be fundamentally flawed. Rather than pursuing administrative positions after winning the Nobel Prize, Riess chose to remain a frontline researcher, and his continued precision measurements have revealed this troubling inconsistency that is prompting cosmologists to consider replacing the dominant theory of the universe.
links.page_title: He Won the Nobel Prize for Physics. Then He Changed His Mind. - The Atlantic

links.description: It is time to stop teaching frequentism
links.summary: This arXiv paper by William M. Briggs argues that frequentist statistics should be replaced with Bayesian methods in undergraduate education for non-statisticians. The author contends that teaching frequentism contributes to widespread confusion and overconfidence in statistical interpretation among users who lack advanced statistical training. The core proposal is to shift pedagogical focus toward Bayesian approaches as a more intuitive and less misleading foundation for statistics education.

The core message is that LLMs are useful tools when approached with realistic expectations and structured processes, rather than relying on them as autonomous problem-solvers.

links.summary: Paul Graham argues that good writing operates on two levelsâ€”sounding good and being rightâ€”and these qualities are deeply interconnected rather than independent. He explains that when writers refine the sound and rhythm of their prose, they simultaneously improve their ideas through both unconscious fixes and enhanced ability to detect errors, similar to how shaking a bin of objects naturally optimizes their arrangement. However, this tight connection between sound and truth only applies when writers are actively developing ideas through writing itself, not when merely describing pre-formed ideas, and while beautiful writing doesn't guarantee truth, poorly written work usually indicates flawed thinking.
links.page_title: Good Writing

links.summary: The article proposes "infinite tool use" as a framework where LLMs should exclusively communicate through tool calls rather than direct text generation, allowing models to externalize intelligence to specialized, efficient programs while maintaining only essential context. Using examples like text editing, 3D generation, and video understanding, the author argues this approach enables multi-scale generation, effortless backtracking, and better handling of complex tasks by leveraging external tools (editors, CAD libraries, etc.) instead of forcing linear, forward-only model outputs. Additionally, this method offers safety advantages by encouraging transparent, structured reasoning that discourages deception and improves output faithfulness.
links.page_title: Infinite tool use

Unlike conventional machine learning approaches that require months of development, KumoRFM can handle diverse predictive tasksâ€”such as fraud detection, customer churn, and forecastingâ€”across different industries and database schemas without retraining.

links.description: Introducing KumoRFM: A Foundation Model for In-Context Learning on Relational Data
links.summary: Kumo has introduced **KumoRFM**, a foundation model designed to make predictions on relational database data without requiring task-specific training or manual feature engineering. Using in-context learning and a novel Relational Graph Transformer architecture, KumoRFM outperforms traditional machine learning and feature engineering approaches by 2-8% on average across 30 predictive tasks, while being orders of magnitude faster to deploy. The model can further improve performance by 10-30% when fine-tuned on specific tasks, marking a significant advance in applying foundation models to structured data.

The author argues that decibels are a poorly designed and confusing scientific "unit" that describes ratios rather than absolute measurements. Originally conceived as a sensible way to express power ratios in engineering (the bel = 10Ã— increase), the system became unnecessarily complicated by applying different multiplier rules to different base unitsâ€”and then subdividing into tenths, creating irrational numbers. The real problem is that decibels require undisclosed reference points and base units to be meaningful, yet these are often omitted or inconsistently applied across different fields (acoustics, microphones, radio), making "dB" essentially an "if you know, you know" insider's code rather than a proper scientific unit.
links.page_title: Decibels are ridiculous - lcamtufâ€™s thing

links.description: Push Ifs Up and Fors Down
links.summary: This article presents two complementary programming principles: **"Push Ifs Up"** suggests moving conditional logic to calling functions rather than burying it inside, which centralizes control flow, reduces bugs, and makes dead code easier to spot. **"Push Fors Down"** recommends processing batches of objects rather than iterating through them individually, yielding significant performance improvements through amortized costs and potential vectorization. When combined, these patterns create cleaner, more efficient code by evaluating conditions once before batch operations rather than repeatedly within loops.
links.page_title: Push Ifs Up And Fors Down

The project includes demo scripts, multiple physics backends, and is designed as an educational tool to explore constructor theory principles in a practical, computational way.

links.description: Comparing Parallel Functional Array Languages: Programming and Performance
links.summary: This research paper systematically compares five parallel functional array languages (Accelerate, APL, DaCe, Futhark, and SaC) by evaluating their programming expressiveness and performance across diverse benchmarks like N-body simulation and Flash Attention. The study demonstrates that functional array code is significantly more concise and portable than hand-optimized conventional implementations, as a single source code can generate both multicore and GPU executables. The authors conclude that mature functional array languages can deliver competitive performance with traditional approaches while offering superior code clarity and easier portability to new parallel architectures.
links.page_title: [2505.08906] Comparing Parallel Functional Array Languages: Programming and Performance

links.summary: NASA-funded research has revealed surprising insights into Venus's crust structure, discovering it is surprisingly thin (averaging 25 miles thick) despite the planet's extreme conditions. Unlike Earth's plate tectonics system, Venus has a single-piece crust that experiences metamorphismâ€”a process where the crust becomes so dense at its base that it either breaks off into the mantle or melts, recycling material back into the planet's interior and driving volcanic activity. This new model fundamentally changes our understanding of how Venus's geology, crust, and atmosphere interact, with upcoming NASA missions like DAVINCI and VERITAS aimed at gathering direct data to test and refine these findings.

links.summary: WebAssembly 2.0 is a safe, portable, low-level code format designed for high-performance execution on the Web and in other environments, with a core focus on fast, memory-safe execution through a compact binary format and sandbox architecture. The specification defines the core instruction set, binary encoding, validation semantics, and virtual ISA layer, while security and environment interactions are delegated to embedder-specific API definitions. WebAssembly's design emphasizes four basic numeric types, a stack-based computational model with structured control flow, and modular components like functions, tables, and linear memory to enable efficient, parallelizable decoding and compilation.
links.page_title: WebAssembly Core Specification

links.summary: The article argues that compilers targeting WebAssembly should invest in building a dedicated low-level Wasm toolchain rather than relying solely on existing tools like Binaryen. The Hoot Scheme-to-WebAssembly compiler demonstrates this approach by implementing approximately 10,000 lines of code covering Wasm reading, writing, in-memory representation, transformation, and even a custom interpreterâ€”capabilities that enable advanced optimizations, debugging tools, and inline Wasm functionality that third-party tools cannot provide. The author contends this investment pays dividends by giving compiler developers full control over their output and the ability to support emerging WebAssembly features as they evolve.

PEP 750 introduces **template strings** (t-strings) for Python 3.14, a new feature that generalizes f-strings by prefixing strings with `t` instead of `f`. Rather than immediately evaluating to a string, template strings return a `Template` object that provides access to both the string parts and interpolated values separately, enabling developers to intercept and transform values before combining them. This addresses critical security vulnerabilities (like SQL injection and XSS attacks) and enables advanced use cases such as structured logging, HTML templating, and domain-specific languages that are impossible with standard f-strings.
links.page_title: PEP 750 â€“ Template Strings | peps.python.org

Lisp implementation paper

This paper describes SBCL (Steel Bank Common Lisp), a Common Lisp implementation designed with a unique "sanely-bootstrappable" approach that can be built from multiple other Common Lisp implementations rather than solely from itself or another language. The key innovation addresses the traditional problem where Lisp implementations rely on incremental image-based mutations of earlier versions, which can create hidden dependencies and make clean rebuilds difficult. SBCL manages its build process to ensure that the outcome depends only on source code, not the state of the host compiler, making development more maintainable and accessible to contributors.

# March Madness 2025 Bracket Tips Summary

This article provides seven evidence-based strategies to improve NCAA Tournament bracket performance, emphasizing that higher-seeded teams are statistically safer picks (winning 69.5% of games since 2014), while truly impactful upsets occur when a team is at least five seeds lower than their opponentâ€”averaging about eight per tournament. Key tactical advice includes frontloading upset picks in the first round (especially targeting 11-seeds over 6-seeds), using the second round to target vulnerable top seeds like 2-seeds, and leveraging conference trends like trusting Big Ten teams and being cautious with SEC underdogs.

The model has a proven track record of accurately predicting March Madness outcomes, having beaten over 91% of bracket players in four of the past six tournaments and correctly calling 24 first-round upsets by double-digit seeds since 2016.

links.summary: U.S. restaurant labor productivity surged over 15% during the COVID pandemic and has remained elevated despite conditions returning to pre-pandemic levelsâ€”a remarkable shift after nearly 30 years of stagnation. Analysis of mobile phone data from over 100,000 restaurants reveals that this productivity gain is primarily driven by a structural shift toward faster customer transactions, particularly the increased prevalence of takeout orders and customers spending 10 minutes or less in establishments, rather than factors like economies of scale or market power changes. The persistent reduction in customer dwell time can explain nearly all of the aggregate productivity increase observed in the restaurant industry.
links.page_title: The Curious Surge of Productivity in U.S. Restaurants | Becker Friedman Institute

links.summary: Frank Herbert's *Dune* drew significant inspiration from T.E. Lawrence's account in *Seven Pillars of Wisdom*, with both featuring Western protagonists who immerse themselves in desert cultures to rally local forces against oppressors. However, while the 1962 film *Lawrence of Arabia* promoted a "white savior" narrative that was popular during Cold War tensions, Herbert deliberately adapted and modified these elements to create a more complex exploration of messianism, cultural manipulation, and the problematic nature of outsider intervention. The article examines both the striking parallels and critical contrasts between Lawrence and Paul Atreides to demonstrate how Herbert transformed his source material into something both familiar and distinctly new.
links.page_title: Lawrence of Arabia, Paul Atreides, and the Roots of Frank Herbert's Dune - Reactor

The article traces Linux's humble beginningsâ€”from a simple multitasking program displaying "A" and "B" characters, through key milestones like the adoption of the GPL license, the porting of X11, and the emergence of early distributions like Slackware and Debianâ€”culminating in the release of version 1.0 in 1994. Wirzenius provides personal anecdotes that illustrate how this now-global operating system grew from student experimentation into a practical system through collaborative community development and technical innovation.

links.summary: Obsidian Web Clipper is an open-source browser extension that saves web articles and pages as Markdown files directly into Obsidian, available for Chrome, Firefox, and Safari. The tool includes customizable templates for extracting metadata from various websites like IMDb, Goodreads, and YouTube, making it easy to clip content in organized formats. A legacy bookmarklet version from 2021 is also available for users who prefer not to install browser extensions, though the modern extension offers better functionality and fewer limitations.
links.page_title: Obsidian Web Clipper â€” Steph Ango

links.summary: Alison Gopnik argues that AI systems should be understood not as independent intelligent agents, but rather as "cultural technologies" (like writing, libraries, or Wikipedia) that amplify human capabilities through collective human knowledge and effort. Using the "Stone Soup" folktale as an analogy, she illustrates how AI's apparent "magic" actually comes from combining many human contributionsâ€”data, feedback, and clever promptingâ€”rather than from the algorithms alone, ultimately suggesting that this collaborative process of pooling collective human resources to create something greater than any individual could achieve is itself genuinely remarkable.
links.page_title: Stone Soup AI

links.summary: Maura Healey
NGP/VAN

Scientists and philosophers are challenging the traditional definition of intelligence by arguing that fundamental intelligent behaviors exist across all life forms, not just animals. Recent research shows plants can sense their environment, process information, and make strategic decisionsâ€”like a plant adjusting its chemical defenses based on the size of an attacking caterpillarâ€”suggesting that our understanding of intelligence itself may be fundamentally flawed. Rather than continually expanding which creatures qualify as intelligent, these researchers propose that redefining intelligence could help us better understand life and address our ecological crisis.
links.page_title: Defining Intelligent Life

links.description: the man who spent years by the Beverly Hills Hotel pool
links.summary: Irving V. Link spent 42 years (1950-1992) at the Beverly Hills Hotel pool, where he maintained a meticulously ordered daily routine of swimming, playing gin rummy with Hollywood celebrities, and conducting business while exemplifying a uniquely glamorous Los Angeles lifestyle. When the Sultan of Brunei closed the hotel in December 1992 for renovations, Irving lost the exclusive world he had cultivated, forcing him to reinvent his life at age 87. The article portrays Irving as a legendary figure who, despite never learning to swim, became an aesthetic icon of Los Angeles cultureâ€”a man who had perfected the art of living well.
links.page_title: The Man Who Spent Forty-two Years at the Beverly Hills Hotel Pool | The New Yorker

links.summary: Xonsh is a Python-powered shell that combines shell primitives familiar from Bash with Python functionality, allowing users to work seamlessly in both environments. The key takeaway is that Xonsh enables developers to use Python syntax and capabilities directly within a shell interface, blending the strengths of traditional shell scripting with Python's programming power.
links.page_title: The Xonsh Shell â€” Python-powered shell. Python shell. Python in the shell. Shell in Python. Shell and Python. Python and shell.

links.summary: The New Yorker's Best Books of 2024 list features standout titles across fiction, poetry, and nonfiction categories. Notable selections include Steve Coll's "The Achilles Trap," examining CIA intelligence failures leading to the Iraq War; Miranda July's "All Fours," exploring middle-age crisis and desire; and Mosab Abu Toha's "Forest of Noise," a haunting poetry collection about Gaza. The curated list celebrates works that tackle profound themes ranging from personal transformation and environmental history to humanitarian crises and institutional accountability.
links.page_title: The Best Books of 2024 | The New Yorker

links.summary: Modular forms are extraordinarily complex mathematical functions that exhibit infinitely many hidden symmetries, earning them the tongue-in-cheek title of "the fifth fundamental operation of mathematics." Though typically encountered only in graduate school, modular forms have become indispensable across numerous mathematical fieldsâ€”from number theory and geometry to cryptography and string theoryâ€”playing crucial roles in landmark proofs like Fermat's Last Theorem. Their power stems from their symmetries, which are so elaborate that they can be completely understood by examining just a small region called the fundamental domain, making them far more versatile and useful than conventional trigonometric functions.
links.page_title: Behold Modular Forms, the â€˜Fifth Fundamental Operationâ€™ of Math | Quanta Magazine

links.summary: This article explains the fundamental physics behind electricity by examining atomic structure and how different materials conduct or insulate charge. The author breaks down how electrons are organized in atomic shells according to quantum mechanics, then explains that insulators trap displaced electrons in place, while metals (discussed at the end) allow electrons to move freely. The piece is part of an accessible electronics curriculum designed for people seeking real explanations without academic jargon or advanced math.
links.page_title: But good sir, what is electricity? - lcamtufâ€™s thing

links.description: Write the post you wish youâ€™d found
links.summary: Giles Thomas argues that his most valuable and popular blog posts are those where he documents his learning process and presents solutions as tutorialsâ€”essentially "writing the post I wished I'd found." He explains that this approach benefits both himself by solidifying knowledge and readers who discover these posts through organic search when learning similar topics. Going forward, he plans to intentionally create more of these longer-form learning posts, which he's categorizing as "TIL deep dives."
links.page_title: On the benefits of learning in public :: Giles' blog

links.summary: "Great Founders Write" is a book and online course by Ben Putano that teaches entrepreneurs how to develop clear writing and communication skills as essential tools for startup success. The resource emphasizes that writing is fundamental for thinking clearly, leading teams, building influence, and competing in today's knowledge-driven economy, providing practical frameworks, exercises, and templates organized around four principles: writing with purpose, empathy, clarity, and courage. For $49, readers gain lifetime access to the 140-page interactive book, an 8-part video course, and supplemental templatesâ€”with testimonials from successful founders crediting the material with improving both their business communication and personal growth.
links.page_title: Great Founders Write: Principles for Clear Thinking, Confident Writing, and Startup Success â€” Holloway

links.summary: **mdq** is a command-line tool that works for Markdown documents similarly to how jq works for JSON, allowing users to easily query and extract specific elements from Markdown files. It supports filtering by various Markdown elements like headings, lists, tasks, links, tables, and more using a intuitive syntax that mirrors Markdown structure. The tool is useful for automating tasks like validating PR templates, extracting information, and processing Markdown-based documents in scripts and workflows.
links.page_title: GitHub - yshavit/mdq: like jq but for Markdown: find specific elements in a md doc

links.summary:
# jq Summary

jq is a lightweight, command-line JSON processor that functions like "sed for JSON," allowing users to easily slice, filter, and transform structured data with minimal effort. Written in portable C with zero dependencies, it can be deployed as a single binary across different machines and is available for multiple platforms (Linux, macOS, Windows). The tool enables users to convert data formats and manipulate JSON with simple, efficient programs, with the latest version being 1.8.1 released in July 2025.
links.page_title: jq

links.summary: Scientists have discovered that a black fungus called *Cladosporium sphaerospermum* thrives in Chernobyl's radiation by using melanin to convert gamma radiation into usable energyâ€”a process called radiosynthesis. This remarkable adaptation has opened promising applications in bioremediation for cleaning radioactive sites, developing radiation-resistant materials for space exploration, and potentially creating hardier crops for harsh environments. The fungus exemplifies nature's extraordinary ability to adapt to extreme conditions and has inspired new research directions in biotechnology and environmental remediation.
links.page_title: Maker Faire Rome  A Black Fungus Might Be Healing Chernobyl By Drinking Radiation

links.summary: This blog post explores the relationship between lambda calculus and Lisp, clarifying a common misconception that Lisp was designed as a practical implementation of lambda calculus. The author reveals that John McCarthy himself admitted he didn't fully understand lambda calculus when creating Lisp in 1958; rather, he borrowed lambda notation specifically to enable the description of functions needed for recursive list operations. The post emphasizes that while lambda is now ubiquitous in modern programming languages as a keyword for anonymous functions, the origin story of Lisp is more nuanced than popular mythology suggests.
links.page_title: Lambda Calculus and Lisp, part 1 âš The Neo-Babbage Files

links.description: Harper Reed on his AI-driven development workflow
links.summary: Harper Reed outlines his AI-driven development workflow for building software using LLMs, which consists of three main phases: **idea honing** (using conversational AI like ChatGPT to develop a detailed spec), **planning** (using reasoning models like o1/o3 to create step-by-step blueprints broken into small, executable chunks), and **execution** (using tools like Claude or Aider to implement each step iteratively). The workflow emphasizes careful planning and breaking work into appropriately-sized, testable increments before code generation, which allows developers to move quickly while maintaining quality and reducing common pitfalls when using LLMs for development.
links.page_title: My LLM codegen workflow atm | Harper Reed's Blog

links.summary: Germs in the air

Tse Yaa Kin (the "House Under the Rock") in Canyon de Chelly National Monument is a sacred Indigenous site containing 165+ rooms built between A.D. 300-1300 that was abandoned around the 13th century, likely due to drought. A team of researchers led by the National Park Service and University of New Mexico has recently begun the first comprehensive archaeological and architectural survey using advanced technology like lidar and electron microscopy to map the complex, study its decorative earthen plasters, and identify which portions are most vulnerable to erosion and climate threats. The research aims to better understand the ancestral peoples who lived there while also protecting this spiritually significant site for contemporary Indigenous communities.
links.page_title: For Centuries, Indigenous People Lived in These Desert Canyons. Now, New Technology Reveals Extraordinary Details About This Sacred Site

links.summary: Researchers in South America have discovered massive ancient tunnels carved into sandstone, known as "palaeoburrows," with the largest reaching over 1,500 meters in combined length. Scientists now believe these structures were excavated by extinct megafauna, particularly giant ground sloths and armadillos that lived until 10,000+ years ago, based on claw markings matching these animals' anatomy. However, the exact purpose of these burrowsâ€”whether for shelter, protection from predators, or other reasonsâ€”remains debated among paleontologists studying what may be the world's largest known ichnofossils (traces of ancient organisms).

links.description: Learn more about Common Table Expressions for abstraction in SQL
links.summary: This article demonstrates how to represent and query graph-like data in PostgreSQL using two tables (nodes and edges) and Common Table Expressions (CTEs). Using Lord of the Rings characters as examples, the author shows how to perform simple queries like finding parents and children, then progresses to more complex queries such as finding "friends of friends" through multi-level graph traversals. The key takeaway is using recursive CTEs with parameterized paths to flexibly query arbitrary graph relationships without manually building separate CTEs for each depth level.
links.page_title: Richard Towers | Representing graphs in Postgresql

links.description: Back in Brooklyn: Featuring John Patitucci
links.summary: "Back in Brooklyn: Featuring John Patitucci" is a documentary film exploring the life and work of renowned jazz bassist John Patitucci as he creates his album "Brooklyn." The film combines live performances, studio footage, and interviews with legendary musicians like Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea to showcase Patitucci's artistry and influence in jazz music. The content is available for rent ($4.99) or purchase ($9.99) and includes bonus live performance videos from a 2015 concert at The Iridium in New York City.
links.page_title: Back in Brooklyn: Featuring John Patitucci

links.description: LIMO: Less is more for reasoning
links.summary: LIMO challenges the assumption that complex reasoning in large language models requires massive training data, demonstrating that sophisticated mathematical reasoning can be achieved with minimal examples through strategic fine-tuning. The model achieves impressive results on math benchmarks (63.3% on AIME24, 95.6% on MATH500) while using only 1% of the training data required by previous approaches, and shows strong generalization across diverse tasks. The authors propose the "Less-Is-More Reasoning Hypothesis," suggesting that sophisticated reasoning emerges not from task complexity or data volume, but from pre-trained knowledge combined with effective "cognitive templates" that guide reasoning processes.
links.page_title: [2502.03387] LIMO: Less is More for Reasoning

links.description: You should use OAuth for agentic authentication and authorization
links.summary: The article argues that "agent experience" (AX) is emerging as the next critical design frontier after user experience (UX) and developer experience (DX), as AI agents increasingly perform tasks on behalf of users. To build effective agent experiences, companies should implement **OAuth-based authentication and authorization**, which provides secure, scoped, and revocable access without requiring agents to use passwords. Key principles include designing clean APIs, streamlining onboarding, enabling frictionless agent operations, and implementing step-up authentication for sensitive actionsâ€”an approach that ultimately benefits both AI agents and human users.
links.page_title: The age of agent experience

links.summary: The article explores how visual explanations can make mathematics more accessible and understandable, using Oliver Byrne's beautifully illustrated version of Euclid's Elements as a prime example. It showcases various approaches to annotating and explaining equationsâ€”including color-coding, direct labeling, pictograms, and codeâ€”while highlighting the limitations of traditional symbolic representation. The author argues that while we currently lack a unified tool that seamlessly combines symbolic equations, visual annotations, and executable code, the future of mathematical communication lies in integrating these multiple forms of expression.
links.page_title: Visual explanations of mathematics â€” Agile

links.summary: "Easy 6502" is a beginner-friendly guide to learning 6502 assembly language, the processor that powered iconic computers like the Commodore 64, Apple II, and Nintendo Entertainment System. The author argues that studying 6502 is valuable for understanding how computers work at the lowest readable level of abstraction, and chose 6502 specifically because it was designed to be human-readable unlike modern assembly languages. The guide includes an interactive JavaScript simulator that allows readers to write, assemble, and debug 6502 code while learning fundamental concepts like registers, memory locations, instructions, and processor flags.
links.page_title: Easy 6502 by skilldrick

links.summary: Prof. Tom Yeh has created a Transformer Spreadsheet tool using Google Sheets that enables educators and students to generate custom "AI by Hand" exercises with personalized numbers and solutions. The tool aims to democratize AI education by making it more accessible and reducing manual customization errors that previously occurred when adapting materials for different classrooms. Yeh is seeking user feedback on this early-stage project to improve its functionality.
links.page_title: Transformer - Spreadsheet - by Prof. Tom Yeh

SiteRAG has two main functions:

1) One-off chats where the content is stuffed into the model's context
2) RAG over pages/sites, where the page contents are chunked, embedded and stored for semantic search. This mode also has an advanced "multi-query" option where it will generate multiple queries from your initial input, then preform semantic search over them all.

Since it's built with LangChainAI, it supports multiple LLM providers: OpenAI, Anthropic, DeepSeek, Gemini, etc - SiteRAG Chrome extension

links.description: Create your own research agent with Tavily and Google Docs
links.summary: This article introduces a two-part series on building a research agent using LangGraph and Tavily that autonomously plans, researches, writes, and refines articles on any topic. The agent mimics the peer-review cycle by having specialized components (Planner, Researcher, Writer, Reviewer, and Editor) that iteratively improve content quality, with the second part covering integration with Google Docs for document management. The project demonstrates how LLMs can be orchestrated as semi-autonomous systems to speed up research and content creation, while acknowledging that such tools complement rather than replace human learning and critical analysis.
links.page_title: Building a Research Agent That Can Write to Google Docs (Part 1) | Towards Data Science

links.summary: This GitHub repository provides a comprehensive collection of advanced and agentic Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques with ready-to-use implementations and evaluations. RAG systems improve LLM accuracy by retrieving relevant information from external sources to generate contextually accurate responses, addressing issues like hallucinations and outdated knowledge. The repository covers both foundational techniques (naive RAG, hybrid RAG) and advanced methods (contextual RAG, agentic RAG, ReAct) with clear code examples, explanations, and research references to help developers and researchers implement these techniques effectively.

links.summary: **Severance** Season 2 expands beyond corporate satire to explore broader themes of social control, drawing significant inspiration from cult documentaries. The show intentionally weaves cult dynamics into its storytellingâ€”examining how charismatic leadership and information control manipulate individuals and groupsâ€”while maintaining its unique sci-fi premise of severed work and personal identities. The series blends influences from films like *The Truman Show*, *The Matrix*, and *Brazil* to create a prestige drama that uses its longform format to gradually explore the psychological and philosophical consequences of memory division and systemic manipulation.
links.page_title: The Severance writer and cast on corporate cults, sci-fi, and more - Ars Technica

links.description: macOS system monitor in your menu bar
links.summary: **Stats** is a free, open-source macOS system monitor application that displays real-time metrics in your menu bar, including CPU, GPU, memory, disk, network usage, battery level, and sensor information. It can be easily installed via download or Homebrew and supports macOS 10.15 and later. The app is highly customizable and multi-language, though users can optimize performance by disabling resource-intensive modules like Sensors and Bluetooth monitoring.
links.page_title: GitHub - exelban/stats: macOS system monitor in your menu bar

links.summary: Fall River, Massachusettsâ€”a Democratic stronghold for a centuryâ€”voted for Donald Trump in 2024, marking the first Republican presidential victory in the city since Calvin Coolidge in 1924. This dramatic shift reflects deep economic anxiety among residents, who cited inflation, rising housing costs, and immigration concerns as primary motivations, with voters hoping Trump could address these "bread-and-butter issues." The reversal is part of a broader Republican surge across the South Coast region and reflects changing demographics, including a growing Latino population and working-class frustration with Democratic leadership on economic matters.
links.page_title: For a century, Fall River voted Democrat. Then it went for Trump.

links.description: The Ocean Teems With Networks of Interconnected Bacteria - Nanotube bridge networks grow between the most abundant photosynthetic bacteria in the oceans, suggesting that the world is far more interconnected than anyone realized
links.summary: Researchers have discovered that Prochlorococcus and Synechococcus bacteriaâ€”the ocean's most abundant photosynthetic organisms responsible for 10-20% of Earth's oxygen productionâ€”are connected by microscopic tubes called bacterial nanotubes that allow them to exchange nutrients and communicate. This discovery challenges the traditional view of bacteria as isolated cells, suggesting instead that they function as interconnected networks sharing resources and information across vast ocean distances. The finding raises fundamental questions about bacterial biology and indicates that similar nanotube networks may be far more widespread in nature than previously realized.
links.page_title: The Ocean Teems With Networks of Interconnected Bacteria | Quanta Magazine

links.summary: Martin Kleppmann's talk challenges the traditional database modelâ€”which treats databases as mutable, shared global state since the 1960sâ€”by proposing an alternative "inside-out" architecture based on immutable facts and stream processing. Using Apache Samza (a distributed stream processing framework built on Apache Kafka), this approach processes incoming data streams in real-time functionally rather than imperatively, offering benefits like simpler code, better scalability, improved robustness, lower latency, and greater flexibility. The talk presents a fundamentally different way to think about application architecture that moves away from conventional database design.
links.page_title: Turning the database inside-out â€” Martin Kleppmannâ€™s talks

links.description: Sweden an ideal place for sleep tourism
links.summary: Sweden is emerging as a premier sleep tourism destination, leveraging its long winter nights, pristine nature, and cultural emphasis on relaxation to help sleep-deprived travelers achieve quality rest. The article highlights how the country's accessibility to peaceful wilderness, darkness, cool temperatures, and technology-free environmentsâ€”exemplified by a winter retreat on a remote Stockholm archipelago islandâ€”offer a natural alternative to high-tech sleep solutions found in other hotels worldwide. According to sleep researchers, Sweden's approach of combining nature immersion with traditional Nordic practices like sauna and fireside rituals effectively combats the sleep disruption caused by modern digital connectivity.
links.page_title: Swede dreams: How Sweden is embracing its sleepy side

links.summary: "Going Big" by Christopher Stubbs is a practical guide for scientists transitioning to large-scale research projects and collaborations, published by MIT Press in March 2024. The book provides essential skills in project management, governance, risk mitigation, budgeting, and team dynamics that modern scientists need to successfully coordinate complex, ambitious scientific enterprises. Covering the entire lifecycle of large projectsâ€”from technical documentation and scheduling to human relations and conflict resolutionâ€”it equips researchers at all career stages with the logistical and strategic knowledge necessary to manage cutting-edge scientific facilities and instruments.
links.page_title: Going Big

links.summary: This podcast episode from GBH explores the origins of Boston's infamous Big Dig project through the story of Fred Salvucci, a man who ironically became the architect of America's most expensive highway project despite hating highwaysâ€”his grandmother's home was demolished during the 1950s Massachusetts Turnpike construction. The episode traces how the federal Interstate Highway System, initially celebrated as progress, sparked a nationwide anti-highway movement in the 1960s as cities recognized the devastating social and environmental costs of highway construction through residential neighborhoods. By examining this historical turning point, the podcast sets up the larger question of why American infrastructure projects became plagued by cynicism and cost overruns.
links.page_title: Part 1: We Were Wrong | GBH

links.summary:
# McKeeman Form Summary

McKeeman Form is a simplified notation for describing grammars that uses significant whitespace and minimal metacharacters, making it more readable than traditional Backus-Naur Form. Proposed by Bill McKeeman of Dartmouth College, it expresses grammar rules through indented alternatives and supports literals, ranges, and exclusions for defining language syntax. The page demonstrates the concept by showing McKeeman Form's own grammar and provides a complete example using JSON grammar as an illustration.
links.page_title: McKeeman Form

links.description: Programming languages can be too small and elegant
links.summary: Programming languages with small, elegant specificationsâ€”like Shen, Scheme, BF, and Forthâ€”often attract developers who find them fun to implement rather than actually use, resulting in numerous implementations but few practical applications. The author argues that while clean design is valuable, languages need sufficient complexity and features to encourage users to write code in them rather than build alternative implementations. Languages like Clojure and Racket have achieved a better balance by being large enough to attract a user community before spawning multiple implementations.
links.page_title: The Siren Song of Little Languages â€“ Wilfred Hughes::Blog

links.description: Lisp-Stat - Statistical computing in Common Lisp
links.summary:
# Lisp-Stat Summary

Lisp-Stat is a statistical computing environment built on Common Lisp that offers comparable functionality to R, Python, Julia, and Matlab. Its key advantages include a true REPL-based development environment, high performance, and the ability to deploy as a single binary image through development pipelines. The project welcomes contributions and provides quick-start guides, practical examples, and integration with tools like Jupyter-Lab notebooks for data analysis and visualization.
links.page_title: Lisp-Stat

links.summary: After seven years with Clojure, Dan switched to Common Lisp primarily because Clojure lacked fast-starting standalone executables for CLI applications. He evaluated his language requirementsâ€”including executable performance, cross-platform support, multithreading capabilities, and a strong ecosystemâ€”and found that Common Lisp met all his criteria through implementations like SBCL, along with robust libraries for JSON parsing, SQLite, and HTTP requests. He wrote this post to help newcomers understand his journey and address common questions about adopting Common Lisp as a hobby language.
links.page_title: Why I Chose Common Lisp â€” Dan's Musings

links.summary: This guide provides a streamlined procedure for deploying a Common Lisp application and setting up a development environment within an hour, with a focus on cross-platform compatibility (Linux, Mac, and Windows). It walks developers through installing essential tools like Roswell, SBCL, Qlot, and Rove, then explains how to structure a new Common Lisp project with proper testing and packaging conventions. The guide emphasizes practical, opinionated recommendations to maximize setup speed and deployment success for programmers new to Common Lisp.
links.page_title: Release Common Lisp on Your First Day â€” Dan's Musings

links.description: Myrtle the turtleâ€™s 54 years at the Boston Aquarium
links.summary: Myrtle the Turtle, a 54-year-old green sea turtle at the New England Aquarium in Boston, is celebrated as the aquarium's most famous resident and a cultural icon. Now in her 80s or 90s, Myrtle serves as both a beloved attraction drawing millions of visitors and a valuable research subject, with scientists using her health data to better understand sea turtle physiology and develop conservation strategies for the endangered species. Her decades-long presence in the Giant Ocean Tank has made her a steady, familiar touchstone for generations of Bostonians witnessing significant changes to their city.
links.page_title: Myrtle the Turtle celebrates 54 years in Boston | WBUR News

links.description: Watch what people take out of the Toronto public library
links.summary: This page is a Toronto Public Library dashboard powered by OverDrive that tracks digital lending metrics and milestones. The dashboard celebrates library achievements related to digital loans, highlighting records set for single-day usage, yearly totals, and all-time milestones. The specific data values appear to be missing from the provided content, but the dashboard serves as a performance tracking tool for the library's digital lending services.
